Earlier in the movie, someone asked him if he'd ever shot a human instead of a replicant by mistake, and not realising this was a replicant, I assumed that was what was happening in this scene, but no, it turns out that was his target the whole time. I actually had to stop the movie at this point and read the Wikipedia article to figure out what had just happened.I have no idea what anyone likes about this movie. I can only think of two movies I've seen that were more boring than this one - Remember the Light and Barely Legal - at least both of those were less than 90 minutes long. This just goes on and on forever, while you strain your eyes and ears trying to see or hear clearly what's going on.I'd give this a zero if I could, but consider the one star a bonus point for the visuals, even though I don't really care for the style.
reviews.heading: One of the worst movies I have ever seen.

reviews.content: Three very different films with similar stories and themes are Blade Runner (1982), Great Expectations (1946) and Superman II (1980). All three films feature a world where criminals are running wild whilst the oblivious hero is distracted by a difficult love affair that is crippled by a lack of humanity. In all three films the characters are unaware of the forces that are working against them in the world and must bring humanity back into their lives (or in Superman's case Kryptonity) in order to finally deal with the problems that have arisen in their absence. The central issue in all three films is the idea of empathy for other beings and the threat from those in the universe that have none because scarily those people who don't feel empathy can appear to be more powerful than those who do. For this film to work Deckard needs to learn something from Rachel, an Idea he could impart to Batty at the end. Instead our hero seems miserable and lost and so are we in this sea of exquisite visuals with no core of humanity to hold onto. Ridley Scott's idea of making Deckard an Android too adds nothing and just continues the film's failure as a drama. The film continually flirts with meaning but ultimately comes to no lasting conclusion.
reviews.heading: More or Less Human Than Human

reviews.content: After reading the book this movie is based upon, "Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep" I immediately recognized this movie as a slap in the face of it's creator. Plot lines entirely cut, characters renamed or entirely cut, different ending, and a horrendously slower pace. Nearly every aspect of the story beats are completely different. The introspection and dialog between other characters showing the main character's emotions about his profession, the reality of the androids' situation, all of it gone and traded for boilerplate exposition. The primary religion and its ties to the story missing. Rick Deckard's wife not even a thought in the movie. Just a poorly acted, snail pace, lacking accurate story, vanity piece for Ridley Scott to show off his chops and cool set design. If you want a great Cyberpunk story just read the book.
reviews.heading: Complete Disrespect to Philip K. Dick

reviews.content: Blade Runner is a visually spectacular science fiction movie which has aged very well 40 years on. Released in 1982, Blade Runner was originally a box office flop despite receiving excellent reviews, however the movie has since become regarded as a masterpiece. Harrison Ford was fantastic in a darker role following his heroic roles in Star Wars (1977), The Empire Strikes Back (1980) and Raiders of the Lost Ark (1981). The late Rutger Hauer was a delight to watch on screen. Director Ridley Scott can also add this to one of his most memorable movies.Based on Philip K. Dick's story "Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?" Blade Runner takes place in 2019 in a futuristic Los Angeles. Synthetic humans known as replicants are being developed by Dr. Eldon Tyrell (Joe Erkel) of the Tyrell Corporation to work on space colonies as they have been declared illegal on Earth as they are considered to be dangerous. Former LAPD Detective and Blade Runner Rick Deckard (Harrison Ford) is coaxed out of retirement by his boss Captain Bryant (M. Emmett Walsh) to track down four dangerous replicants who have escaped following a spaceship crash. A Blade Runner is responsible for tracking down replicants and to terminate them which is called "retirement". The escapees include Roy Batty (the late Rutger Hauer), Leon (the late Brion James), Pris (Daryl Hannah) and Zhora (Joanna Cassidy). As Deckard hunts down the replicants, he finds himself torn between his duty to retire the replicants as he finds himself falling for Tyrell's assistant Rachel (Sean Young) who may or may not be a replicant.The rest of the cast includes Edward James Olmos as Gaff who is a fellow Blade Runner, William Sanderson as J. F. Sebastian who is a genetic creator, and James Hong as Hannibal Chew who is a genetic engineer that produces eyes for the replicants.There are several versions of Blade Runner that exist including the 1982 theatrical version, the 1992 Director's Cut which removed Harrison Ford's narration, added a unicorn dream sequence, and a darker ambiguous ending. The 2007 Final Cut adds a few smaller scenes and adds the full sequence of the unicorn dream.Blade Runner is still a visually dazzling classic 40 years on and I must say the visual effects and art design has aged very well. Ridley Scott did a superb job and Harrison Ford and Rutger Hauer were fantastic. Blade Runner can also be credited with more of Phillip K. Dick's works being adapted for the screen with movies such as Total Recall (1990), Minority Report (2002), and A Scanner Darkly (2006). It's a shame Blade Runner flopped at the box office in 1982, but thankfully has grown to become more appreciated as time has passed and later became more successful on VHS and with the subsequent releases of the director's cut in 1992 and the final cut in 2007. I still regard Blade Runner as an excellent movie.8/10.
reviews.heading: Step into the world of Ridley Scott's visually spectacular science fiction classic which has aged very well 40 years on.

reviews.content: It concerns a narrator whose recollection of the events may be colored. Some may have happened, some may have been manufactured memories. Within the remembered story are people who fold memories, from the fellow who manufactures replicants, to he who makes 'toys,' to the fellow who literally folds. This first use of noir in scifi underscores the matter: noir denotes a coloring of the world, an implied narrator (usually but not necessarily paranoid).What makes this a watershed is that the studio bosses washed all that out of the theatrical release, making the narrator a trusted one by literally narrating. The film was a flop. With the director's reinstatement of the ambiguous truth, it has become a success. And who says the viewing public is too stupid to appreciate multilevel truths? Even people who think it is a simple story sense something deeper.Harrison Ford as a person is completely clueless about the forces that created, surround and buffet him, so he is a natural for this role, probably his best. Joanna Cassidy (Zhora) is a redhead. Great films seem to have more than their share.This camera is highly architectural. The state of the art with effects did not allow much camera movement, so all the perspectives are borrowed from Welles. So it doesn't innovate there, but the emulation is quite masterful. Where it does innovate is in the vision of an alternative (not future) world, but of course you knew that. However, it is worth noting how rare this is.The combination of knotted truths, architectural camera, effective reinstatement of alternative worlds, and the confused projection of self are completely in line with what Dick intended (if not quite what he wrote). And it is enough to place this in the top three of my best science fiction films, and on my list of must viewing for students of visual thinking.
reviews.heading: Good sci-fi film of the 80's

reviews.content: This is still one of the greatest sci fi movies ever made. Fantastic performances from Ford and Hauer.Scott's direction is superb. Definitely in his top 3.The depth of character development in the midst of high velocity action is mesmerising.And the dystopian setting is the benchmark.Amazing to revisit this classic.
reviews.heading: TIME TO DIE

reviews.content: Even one character we can safely assume is human, the reptilian Tyrell, czar of the corporation which manufactures replicants, strikes me as a possible replicant. And of the hero, Deckard (Harrison Ford), all we can say for sure is that director Ridley Scott has left clues in various versions of his film that can be used to prove that Deckard is a human -- or a replicant. The biggest change Scott made in earlier versions was to drop the voice-over narration from the 1982 original. Spoken by Ford, channeling Philip Marlowe, it explained things on behalf of a studio nervous that we wouldn't understand the film. Since much of the interest in the film has been generated by what we weren't sure we understood, that turned out to be no problem. The ending has been tweaked from bleak to romantic to existential to an assortment of the above, and shots have come and gone, but for me the most important change in the 2007 version is in the print itself. The action follows Deckard, a "blade runner" who is assigned to track down and kill six rebel replicants who have returned illegally from off-worlds to earth, and are thought to be in Los Angeles. (The movie never actually deals with more than five replicants, however, unless, as the critic Tim Dirks speculates, Deckard might be the sixth). Replicants, as you know, are androids who are "more human than human," manufactured to perform skilled slave labor on earth colonies. Ridley Scott is a considerable director who makes no small plans. His credits include "Alien," "Legend," the inexplicable "1492: Conquest Of Paradise," "Gladiator," "Black Hawk Down" and the brilliant "Matchstick Men," and his "American Gangster" opened Friday in theaters. He has the gift of making action on a vast scale seem comprehensible. I have been assured that my problems in the past with "Blade Runner" represent a failure of my own taste and imagination, but if the film was perfect, why has Sir Ridley continued to tinker with it, and now released his fifth version?
reviews.heading: Philosophical

reviews.content: Get ready for a ride! The force of the cinematography is one to behold with dialogue and acting at a level even beyond. This movie is a classic for a reason - it draws you in and projects meaning in layers that I will be thinking about for days. Perhaps the only thing that took me out was reconciling it takes place in a futuristic Los Angeles but rains all the time and otherwise doesn't even look similar; I'm happy to take it as a completely alternate world though in which LA maybe isn't even on the same continent.
reviews.heading: Have a Seat You Can Grip!

reviews.content: I couldn't really agree with myself about this film. On the one hand, the world building is incredibly interesting as are the colors, sets, and costumes. It also had potential into some interesting ideas. On the other hand, the acting was adequate at best, the dialogue felt very eighties goofy, and the score was downright terrible. It's the only movie I can think of where the score actually made it worse. It also chose to forgo any sort of introspection and speculation and laid everything out too plainly in an in your face style. While the last action sequence was quite well done, it lacked power due to the film's inability to create stakes that you felt invested in. It also didn't help that the characters were quite one dimensional and I didn't care about them one bit. But yeah, the visuals and world building were good enough to partially save the film.
reviews.heading: A mixed Bag

reviews.content:
Unbelievable that it achieves perfection in all possible aspects ... I believe it is the greatest classic of science fiction , in a script where with few initial words they already let you know all the news in which the film is set, in 2019 in a decadent Los Angeles, dirty with a lot of oriental culture ( We see ridley Scott's idea of globalization, extinct animals etc... ) to help colonize other planets were created by the Tyrrel industry for commercial purposes "the replicants " artificial human beings with only a little more strength but with their pre-established useful life . The film places them as dangerous beings who can kill at any time fighting for their cause ( which we will later see will be the extension of their life ) but in fact they ended up serving of slaves for the human race and some rebels would come to Earth to try to live among humans so the local police use the bladerunner ( android hunters ) that there are even others but none with the capacity of the main character.The photography is sensational, masterpiece, I loved Tim Burton's Gotham City ambience in Batman 89, only long after I watched Bladerunner , I came to find Gotham without originality after that....
Lights with a lot of contrast all the time, with a lot of brightness and darkness , smoke and rain give the idea of social inequality and where the cyberpunk style originated and puts us in one of the biggest atmospheres ever created.Very well made characters that really work, it is worth highlighting a replicant that cries phenomenally when it learns that its memories are only placed on its consciousness and it is not really human. And yet the director asks us questions to think about the dreams of deckard main character who has dreams if they are natural or just memories introduced.Finally, a film about survival, which we initially think is only of humans but later also of replicants, with much research, a film that is normally slow , with a lot of suspense that puts action very well embedded at the right times. A subtle but important love of a bladerunner for a replicant that makes us wonder if it is really right to exterminate these beings .Very intelligent dialogues throughout the film but the dialogue of the final scene of the leader of the replicants for me is a poetry that was eternalized in the seventh art. Masterpiece.
reviews.heading: Masterpiece

reviews.content: Very much depends on which edition you end up watching. The Director's cut would be my choice. Although any version other than the one with fords totally unconvincing voice over (which also looks a bit shoddy compared to other cuts) would be preferable.
reviews.heading: But which runner?

reviews.content: I have to admit that it took me quite a time after watching this piece of art to come up with some kind of rating and review. It's just type of a movie you need to really think about. Ridley Scott's Blade Runner is undoubtedly remarkable and extraordinary work in so many ways.First of all, it's dark, oppressive noir atmosphere that doesn't leave the viewer even for a second created by setting, always fitting soundtrack, Harrison Ford's charismatic voiceover, impressive amount of attention to details in showing decaying world where 'if you're not cop, you're little people', where you're promised to have a great life somewhere else, far away from here and where it's always rainy and moody. This movie has a style that's for sure. I also love its unhurried, thoughtful narrative. Everyone involved in creating Blade Runner made a magnificent work.Another important thing to point out is definitely movie's phyloshopy that never gives you an easy answers, but make you think about so much. What makes us who we are? Can we be defined by our life experience and memories? Can we be sure those are real? How long do we have before our time is up? What a person think about when dying and how does being close to death affect our values? And so much more eternal questions that we all can have different answers for. Film just gives you a perspective, that's all.Story, characters and the way they are portrayed are also what makes Blade Runner so amazing. The story itself is quite simple but yet good enough. The combination of different genres makes it work. Blade Runner doesn't have characters that are good or bad, it's up to vievew to decide. Because if I personally really dive into the narrative I keep asking myself: are replicants that bad? They were surely desperate, their time was running out and all they wanted was to make it last. It's pretty relatable. And when they were killing, they kept trying to make others feel the way they've been made to feel by being slaves. They may not be humans but they weren't emotionless robots. And the main character? Is he one of the good guys? Blade runners were not supposed to have emotions, basically they were just machines for killing. Rick Deckard is not one of those but is he even human? Film have some hints that leave you uncertain.All that being said, the film has some questionable moments like how didn't they even try to search Leon to make sure he had no guns? Also knowing how good Deckard is at his job, I was expecting him to have some strategy against replicants but, in fact, he was just lucky to stay alive all the time thanks to some cliches. So yes, Blade Runner is not perfect but what movie ever is?
reviews.heading: All he'd wanted were the same answers the rest of us want

reviews.content: It is difficult to overestimate the epochal creation from the famous director Ridley Scott called "Blade Runner". This is now a well-established fiction that has passed the test of time and over a long history has won the favor of viewers around the world, besides revealing the birth of a whole direction, which is now commonly called cyberpunk.Taking as a basis the well-known novel by Philip K. Dick "Do androids dream of electroovtsy?" Sir Ridley supplemented the work, substantially reworked it, breathing something new into his picture. This film was imbued with the atmosphere of the decline of the future, the dominance of various technological innovations, which at the same time, it seems to me, absolutely did not bring joy to people. Society vegetates in a monstrous world of consumption, where a person and his personality are lost among a large crowd. Scott perfectly conveys the atmosphere of an authentic future, playing superbly with dark tones, and tells his story through the prism of a society falling into decline.The genre that was born thanks to this picture is now recognized thanks to the noticeable features of this film. The world here is presented in the form of a night city with the presence of numerous bright neon colors, a lot of advertising signs, frequent rains. Here you will be met by futuristic, but angular cars that fly right in the clouds, corporations rule the world, and artificial people can meet among the inhabitants of the planet. They're replicants.The main character, played by Harrison Ford, will have to face a group of them. He is a representative of a special squad called Blade Runners, who are fighting the appearance of replicants on Earth,. And his mission is to find several dangerous representatives of artificial people in order to prevent their existence on our planet. Ford's hero named Rick Deckard will do this with special interest for observation. The script and direction of the project allow you to plunge into the authentic world of the night metropolis, which is as familiar to everyone living in it as it is just as dangerous for them.The film poses a lot of questions to the audience, the main one of which boils down to drawing a line between real people and artificial ones. The topic is not new and even popular for that time. But, like any author, Philip K. Dick and Ridley Scott, who filmed this book masterpiece, answer this question in their own way.What is the role of man in this world? And who are the replicants? The latter are the offspring of the former, but how different are they? Where is the line between them, because everyone has their own consciousness, memory, and, as I think, feelings. It will be difficult to answer, each viewer will decide for himself which verdict will be right for him.An important heroine, played by Sean Young, will help the viewer and the main character to understand this issue. Her Rachel is shrouded in mystery, she is a special heroine who allows you to better understand this world of people and replicants.The film is complex and viscous. You drown in it, it seems long and slow. However, now, it would seem, these losing moments have become the hallmark of the work. The general plans of a dark city, towering pillars of fire somewhere in the distance, electronic sad music, like the sounds of loneliness of everyone and everyone in this huge metropolis - all this conveys the atmosphere of Scott's work.For this world, as if such wonderful actors as Rutger Hauer, Harrison Ford, Sean Young, Daryl Hannah, Bryon James and others appeared to the world as a selection. A great hit for everyone, the creation of unique and memorable characters.The picture will definitely make you think about the place of a person in the modern world and the future world of the future. Who will live next to us, how will we treat them, will the new artificial creatures pose a threat to people? There are a lot of questions that are quite difficult to answer.But I will never forget that monologue of Rutger Hauer's hero in the finale, his tears in the rain: "I saw things that you people never dreamed of. Attacking ships blazing over Orion; Si rays cutting through the darkness at the gates of Tannhauser. All these moments will be lost in time, like... tears in the rain... It's time to die."It seems that this is the quintessence of the whole work, when not only Deckard will rethink the familiar reality, but the audience along with him.7 out of 10.
reviews.heading: Classics for all time by Ridley Scott

reviews.content: I just don't get Blade Runner. It's a cool concept, but one that I just can't stand behind because of its delivery. Why do robots need to bleed? Why in the world is Harrison Ford the only one going after a bunch of crazy deadly robots? Why not a team? Why do we need romance between a character and a robot? I can completely understand the idea of robots evolving to have emotion and human behaviors, but there's just so much I can't get behind with this movie, and that's where it fails in the end. I don't quite understand the hype. And maybe I just didn't pay attention enough, but I didn't enjoy it as much as I thought it was. The slow pacing didn't make it any better. Not one I really plan on rewatching any time soon.
reviews.heading: I'm Missing the Hype

reviews.content: This has to be one of my favorite sci-fi movies of all time. With beautiful visuals, it's retro futuristic music, a Neo-noir feel and characters that help movie many of the themes of the movie forward. This is one timeless cult classic that I will never get tired of. A movie that will leave you with a foreboding feel from start to finish that makes you have a feel of paranoia. The movie uses literature, religious symbolism and dramatic themes that show how technology has effected us in more ways than one. With asking us to exam humanity and what truly makes us human. Which is why I feel it will never get old cause these are things that we will never truly have an answer for.
reviews.heading: One of my favorite sci-fi movies of all time

reviews.content: I tried watching it many times before but I always gave up due to the slow pace boring initial scenes so I decided to give it a try again. Unfortunately it doesn't pass the test of time. I can't imagine the movie is based in 2019, I can't get past that. This is probably the biggest script error.So in the future they are able to create human like robots and travel to other planets but use tv monitors from the 70's? I know in 1982 they couldn't have forseen the coming of flat screen TV monitors but it just seems odd. Also, how can the replicas have blood like humans? And again , how can Ford fall in love for a replican? Do they even have sex parts?And yes, I, like others, found the so called sex scene a bit distasteful. You can tell the guy is much older than her and he is kind of forcing her to have sex. Ugly.Visually is great, soundtrack is great but it just doesn't pass the test of time and can be a bit slow at times with some inconsistencies.
reviews.heading: Interesting

reviews.content: Vangelis is the real star of this movie. The soundtrack is minimal, but mesmerizing. The sense of atmosphere is unbelievable. The FinalCut is the only version of Blade Runner that I've seen, and it's brilliant.
reviews.heading: Final Cut! Mesmerizing

reviews.content: Good entertainment. As I'm sure everybody knows there are several versions of the film, my comments are based on the original UK release. This is a prime example of neo-noir cinema with its consistently dark setting, lots of smoking and Harrison Ford's world-weary voice over. Ford plays Deckard, a Blade Runner who's job is to hunt down artificial people known as replicants who used as off world slave labour but aren't permitted on Earth. A group of them have returned and are trying to find their creator. Initially we don't know why they have returned but soon learn that they were built to last only four years and as their time is running out they seek a way to fix themselves.In his pursuit of them he is sent to see the head of the Tyrell corporation, who had designed the replicants. Here Deckard is introduced to Tyrell's assistant Rachael who unbeknownst to her is also a replicant who has been implanted with false memories. When she learns what she is she seeks Deckard again to discover what he knows.When the film starts we know that Deckard is clearly the hero of the film and the replicants, lead by Roy Batty played by Rutger Hauer are the villains but as the film progresses that idea becomes less certain. After all all they want is a life that isn't artificially shortened.The acting from Ford and Sean Young, as Rachael is very good but it is Rutger Hauer who steals the show as the enigmatic Batty, his finally speech is one of the great film speeches. I'd recommend this to all fans of science fiction, especially for people who like them set in a dystopian future.
reviews.heading: Good entertainment

reviews.content: I don't know what people see in this film.By what I can tell from the other reviews, Blade Runner is just earning good reviews from the nostalgia aspect of it. The film, in my opinion, is too weird, doesn't make any sense, and the poor choice of music and unnecessary scenes makes it feel twice as long as it is. Would definitely not recommend watching, unless you're watching it '20 years later and it's still better than the rest' (it definitely isn't). I reckon this film could've been an hour shorter and it would have been just as good, if not better, and spared an hour of my time which was otherwise wasted.
reviews.heading: They made a short film seem like a very long one

reviews.content: I neither think that this movie is a masterpiece or a piece of garbage. I jsut think this movie is "good".I kinda liked the what the movie is tryna tell us, but this not in the area of the movie, rather the book. So I can't take this as a criter.For an 80's movie, I think the cinematography is pretty good, it was elaborate. Not only the futurist scenes, also the inside ones with the puppets and so on. It does not expand my horizons but at least it didn't caught my eye too.I think the "replica" actors really nailed being a replica, as they find the perfect spot between a robot and a human, congrats to Rutger Hauer for this good performance.And that's it. Besides from how this movie affected the "cyberpunk" movie endustry it was a pretty good movie. Also it is kinda philosophical if you are fond of it.
reviews.heading: A Good Movie

reviews.content: Ford is good in this film - this is a prime example of neo-noir cinema with its consistently dark setting, lots of smoking and Harrison Ford's world-weary voice over. Ford plays Deckard, a Blade Runner who's job is to hunt down artificial people known as replicants who used as off world slave labour but aren't permitted on Earth. A group of them have returned and are trying to find their creator. Initially we don't know why they have returned but soon learn that they were built to last only four years and as their time is running out they seek a way to fix themselves.In his pursuit of them he is sent to see the head of the Tyrell corporation, who had designed the replicants. Here Deckard is introduced to Tyrell's assistant Rachael who unbeknownst to her is also a replicant who has been implanted with false memories. When she learns what she is she seeks Deckard again to discover what he knows.When the film starts we know that Deckard is clearly the hero of the film and the replicants, lead by Roy Batty played by Rutger Hauer are the villains but as the film progresses that idea becomes less certain. After all all they want is a life that isn't artificially shortened.The acting from Ford and Sean Young, as Rachael is very good but it is Rutger Hauer who steals the show as the enigmatic Batty, his finally speech is one of the great film speeches.
reviews.heading: Ford is good in this film

reviews.content: If this movie was releases today, it would be considered a comedy. People are howling like wolves for no reason, dialogue is corny and visual effects do not stand the test of time. Premise is kinda cool, but after half of thr movie it just becomes a run and gun film. Also, half of the soundtrack is some kind of sexy sax? Maybe it was cool 40 years ago, but now it feels pretty generic.Hot take - I would rather watch I, Robot.
reviews.heading: Maybe it was cool 40 years ago, but now it feels corny

reviews.content: Heading to the new Blade Runner movie I finally decided to watch the first movie. What a massive disappointment it was. This movie is all looks and zero substance, there is no script, no character development nor interest in the characters, just dark scenes, lots of rain and some boring and dull action scenes.The pace is extremely slow and the story is so simple that the movie could've been much shorter, it is only this big because all they wanted to do was to show you this world that they created, and thats the main problem with this movie, more focused on visuals than substance, they created the story to go along with the world but should've been the other way around.The only reason I rate it 3/10 its due the production and visual impact that this movie had, because otherwise this would be a straight 1/10.
reviews.heading: Overrated and Boring

reviews.content: From start to finish, the atmosphere of this fantastic world is enthralling. The top notch acting kept me engaged with the story, wondering what's going to happen next. I found the opening scene to be especially engrossing. Harrison Ford shines as Deckard and Sean Young is absolutely captivating as Rachael. I love the layers to the plot. The replicant hunter story is fantastic as well as the exploration of replicant development into progressively more intelligent and sentient existence. However, my favorite part is Deckard's journey of self discovery and the big question that the movie asks you to decide: is he a replicant? Highly recommend this film.
reviews.heading: Is he a replicant?

reviews.content: This review is for Blade Runner (1982) the original theatrical release I have also seen the directors cut version.The Noir meets futuristic sets and cinematography are amongst the greatest ever on the screen.The noir plot and pacing is also excellent and so is the score by Vangelis.Harrison Ford is excellent and Ruther Hauer is also an excellent villan. Darryl Hannah is also good.The original has some scenes that have a noir esque voice over which is fine it's neither amazing nor bad.In the original the ending is not as strong and the origami Unicorn at the end is just random.In the directors cut Deckard day dreams about a unicorn so this hints that he might be a replicant.The original is still a 9 out of 10 and the directors cut if it was the only cut would be a 10.I am sticking at 9 though because I hate it when there are several versions of the same film and then you don't know which version you should watch. I also hate it when stuff is added and changed year's after the original release.Studios fault or whatever, it is the Directors responsibility to make sure the best version possible is the only version available.
reviews.heading: The most visually stunning ever made at that point in history.

reviews.content: This movie is (apparently) a cult classic, so I decided to give it a watch. 40 minutes in and I had to stop watching. It's probably the most boring and dragging movie I've ever seen.There's barely anything happening (which in many cases isn't a problem, but here, it makes me go nuts), all of the characters are flat, shallow, unlikeable and annoying, the effects are pretty bad and there's way too much emphasis on them (to me this seems like more of a "style presentation" than a movie, and unfortunately, the style itself isn't anything special), the plot seems weak and pseudo-intelligent and most importantly, this movie simply doesn't live up to its hype. In no way does it deserve eight (eight!) stars, three max., maybe for being something new at the time and for the not too awful acting.I'd recommend this only to those who want to feel like they'd spend the time watching this movie better if they stared at a wall for two hours straight. I'm glad I didn't force myself to watch this any longer, just the 40 minutes were too insufferable.
reviews.heading: Immensely boring and overrated

reviews.content: Probably his greatest work. I think he needs to receive all the praise in the world for contributing to the arresting mood and atmosphere of this film and its world. Can you imagine it with any other score?
reviews.heading: 10/10 for Vangelis

reviews.content: If your curse is accelerated decrepitude, longevity is something that's clearly not accrued, you'll be treated like a slave, when equality is all you crave, in the catastrophic climate you've been skewed.If you try to break the rules and integrate, the only recourse left to them is based on hate, where you're hunted like a dog, through the streets of rain and smog, unavoidably it's time to abdicate.Oozing metaphors from almost every pore, the dreams of unicorns lay behind several locked doors.
reviews.heading: A Drenched & Decrepit Dystopia...

reviews.content: The first time I watched Blade Runner was when I was 16 years old, and I absolutely hated it. I found it boring, slow, and pretentious, and for the life of me could not understand the hype surrounding it. And for about a decade or so, I maintain that same position, even after watching and really enjoying the film's sequel, Blade Runner 2049.However, a few months ago, the Final Cut of the movie appeared on Netflix and I decided to give it another try. I found it more enjoyable the second time around, but still wasn't huge on the movie's final act, which I admittedly didn't understand. After another viewing yesterday, and after digging deeper into the meanings and interpretations behind the film, I can say that, while I don't consider this to be the perfect masterpiece that so many others do, I've grown to truly appreciate and respect Blade Runner for what it is.Loosely based on Philip K. Dick's "Do Androids Dream Of Electric Sheep?", Blade Runner is set in a futuristic 2019 and follows Rick Deckard, a police detective known as a Blade Runner, whose job is to hunt down humanoid robots known as Replicants and "retire" (i.e. Kill) them if necessary. At the beginning of the movie he is commissioned to hunt down four Replicants who are on Earth illegally seeking more life from their creator Tyrell. Along the way, he meets Racheal, a Replicant who doesn't know she's a Replicant, and begins to develop feelings towards her.Visually this film is stunning. The cinematography coupled with the atmosphere and tone of the setting really suck you into the world of Blade Runner, not to mention the score by Vangelis which gives the film a very noir feeling while coupling it with futuristic soundscapes. There are great performances, specifically Harrison Ford and Sean Young, and Rutger Hauer (RIP) delivers a more interesting and two-dimensional villain than we are often accustomed to in sci-fi. While the slow pace was a turn off for me during first viewing, I actually didn't find the movie to be slow or boring on repeated viewings. I actually think the movie is perfectly paced for what it is, and what little action is included in the movie is well orchestrated.Of course what really sells Blade Runner are its themes regarding humanity and what it means to be human. It's very deep and rich in these themes, exploring how these Replicants behave and whether or not they truly feel or have motivation behind their actions. This is especially present in the film's climax, with the famous "Tears In Rain" speech, which is one of the movie's highlights.There is one scene of course that knocks the film down a couple of pegs, and that is the love scene between Deckard and Rachael. To be perfectly blunt, it comes across as creepy and, for lack of a better word, rapey. I don't think that was the intention of the filmmakers, and maybe things were different in the 80s than they are now, but this scene has not aged well and probably never will. I also wish there was a little bit more backstory as to why Earth is the way it is in the movie, but it isn't necessarily vital to the story.Overall, Blade Runner is a really great film that gives you a fully realized world, deep themes, and below the surface characterization. The flaws mentioned above keep it from getting a higher rating, but now I can kind of see why so many people consider this to be a masterpiece in a way that I didn't before. I recommend it if you're a fan of sci-fi; just know that it may take a little while before it clicks with you. It sure did for me.
reviews.heading: Not A Perfect Masterpiece, But One I've Grown To Appreciate More Overtime

reviews.content: Years ago, I read at least a part of Dick's original novel, "Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?" I don't think I read the entire book. Then, when this movie was released, I watched it. Last night my wife and I watched it again, a version called "the final cut," on a rented DVD, and I couldn't believe how utterly and agonizingly boring it was. I'm only posting this review to let the other one-star reviewers know that they are not alone in hating this movie, so there's no need to go into any detail -- suffice it to say, folks, I completely agree with you, this movie is a disaster from start to finish. It leaves me with absolutely no respect whatsoever for the "famous director," or any of the screenwriters, or any of the stars, including Harrison Ford. Bottom line, this feeble excuse for a sci-fi flick is like a really bad and embarrassing joke. May 26, 2022.
reviews.heading: agonizingly boring

reviews.content: I love Blade Runner. It dives into a realistic future with realistic characters, dialog, layouts and events. In fact, this whole movie is really good in the matter of looking like a live video of whats really happening there. The way some questions are left unanswered makes look like it was not presented to an audiance, but its a real thing. The philosophy of this film makes you wonder what is the distinction of being human, or what is the point of life. And this very idea was executed in a very good way. Of course, to me Ridley Scott is the best director for reallism, and this film is a very good example why. Of course the acting was really good and the camera work was pretty good also. One thing i appreciate a lot about this movie is the way you can feel the dirtiness of 2019 Los Angeles. Yes, the way we feel the environement is very important to world building because then we are a lot more invested in the movie and can understand events a lot easier. And it is especialy important with films as ambiguous has Blade Runner. I would say that Blade Runner is a masterpiece in its own way.
reviews.heading: The Ultimate Dirty Future

reviews.content: I know the title of this review is provocative, but I'll stand by it. With due apologies to my sentimental favorite, Star Wars, and to the way-ahead-of-its-time 2001, Bladerunner combines all the elements of great storytelling into a visually stunning picture, and like the best SciFi, asks "the big questions" without sounding preachy about it.So, what IS the big question? Nothing more or less than: What does it mean to be human? Wow.Is an artificially created human life really human? Does that creature have a soul? Is it worthy of all the rights and values we put on human life? What is our responsibility as the creator of such a life?And happily for us, the answers are not clear and can be (and have been) endlessly debated. As I said above, great SciFi asks questions, but the best SciFi doesn't have the arrogance to pretend to have the answers.Philosophy aside, the script, the acting and the cinematography are top-notch. Harrison Ford tops even his fantastic Indiana Jones as our protagonist, Sean Young is stunning and strong and vulnerable as the object of his obsession, and Rutger Hauer gives one of the all-time great movie monologues. Supporting actors are strong throughout and no character or situation is superfluous or just filling screen space and time.An absolute masterpiece.Note: There are several versions of the movie out there. For the best experience, see The Final Cut.
reviews.heading: The Greatest SciFi Movie Of All Time

reviews.content: From a 1982 perspective. "Blade Runner" is set in the dystopian November of 2019, in the city of Los Angeles, where the living population seizes to exist and all the animals have become extinct, though some individuals may have virtual pets as companions. Though played as a cyberpunk, dystopian situated sci-fi movie, the film also succeeds as a film-noir to greater effect. The Tyrell Corporation have created humanoid individuals known as replicants who resemble humans, but more powerful and advanced, but have become illegal to enter Earth. A special police force known as Blade Runners have been assigned to "retire" them.Unlike the traditional noir films, "Blade Runner" has colour, though it's still dark, dreary and rains in every scene. Light of day is absent in in this movie. The environment in this movie is quite infertile, combined with archaic technology, an abnormal looking bluish light, and spaceships that have neon backgrounds. The aesthetic in this movie truly captures the essence of 1980's cinema where the old school technology is compared to the more modern standards. Though the sci-fi genre may have worn out it's welcome over the years, the storytelling featured here is appealing. Underneath the continual raining, "Blade Runner" is very culturally uplifting, with a diverse melting pot of unique people and their customs.Four replicants have invaded Earth and it's up to felloe Blade Runner Rick Deckard (Harrison Ford) to retire them. But looking for them is like easier said than done. But Deckard has the most experience of all the Blade Runners out there.His first quest is to look for the creator of these replicants Dr. Eldon Tyrell (Joe Turkel) and to conduct a test on young woman named Rachael (Sean Young) who might be a replicant, though she might not know if she is one. Deckard conducts the Voight-Kampff test on her and goes further into his investigation. Meanwhile loose replicant Roy Batty (Rutger Hauer) and Leon Kowalski (Brion James) an eye manufacturer for replicant, Hannibal Chew (James Hong) who leads them to a gifted genetic designer J. F. Sebastian (William Sanderson). Meanwhile fellow replicant, Pris (Daryl Hannah) gets invited into Sebastian's home.Deckard's first encounter with a replicant leads him on a trail of snake scales and that is where he meets Zhora (Joanna Cassidy) who poses as a stripper with a computerized snake. Deckard goes incognito while Zhora goes on with her act, but then kills her. Leon knows what had transpired. And tries to get even. With some assistance, Deckard was able to finish off Leon making it two down and two more to go.Roy follows Sebastian to the secret headquarters to Dr. Tyrell's domain where it's been revealed that replicants can only function under a four year lifespan. Roy has some choice words from his creator and they have a conflicting exchange of words. After that heated discussion, Roy gives his master a kiss and then eliminates him. Shortly afterwards, Sebastian met his fate as well. The Roy/Tyrell confrontation can almost be similiar exchanges between Dr. Frankenstein and his creature as both end up questioning their existence.Deckard finds Pris at Sebastian's apartment and gets ambushed, but he later kills her and now it just comes down to Rick and Roy for a climactic showdown. These scenes might look like a mindless cat and mouse chase as each character is looking to destroy one another and at times it appear like both adversaries come across as inhuman. Though we know Roy is a replicant, we even somtimes wonder if Deckard himself is one too. The ending seems to come to a strange, but rather powerful climax. In the end the villain himself ends up saving Deckard from falling to his death while knowing all to well that his days are numbered. He lets out a monologue revealing that his limited time on Earth will be like tears from the rain, lost in time.A mysterious individual named Gaff (Edward James Olmos) a fellow officer who's crafty in origami mentions to Deckard that she too won't have long to live, making us think she might be a replicant. He comes to his apartment and sees Rachael sleeping in his bed and sees the origami unicorn that was made by Gaff. Deckard takes Rachael and drive away without caring if she's a replicant or not.One of the things that make this film stand out is that all the variations of this movie (The Director's Cut, The Final Cut etc.) is that there are different interpretations for each and every one of them. The magic of this film is the allure and the appeal of the fan base it's gotten over the years. And though the happy ending might be a bit cliched and wrapped up way too nicely for its own tastes, it's still a good watch for everyone to enjoy.
reviews.heading: A Sci-Fi That Doesn't Insult Your Intelligence

reviews.content: A really great movie very cult but remember you should watch the director's cut version or the final cut that visually is even better and NOT watch the theatrical cut.
reviews.heading: A must watch movie

reviews.content: I start from the point that pleased me the most, the way the film is conducted, its rhythm is perfect, it left me entertained and satisfied throughout the entire film; The characters and plot dilemmas are another extremely positive point, making everything deeper and making you reflect on, something that few films can; The movie also has beautiful visuals and atmosphere, you can see how much effort they put into this project.One of the best science fiction I've ever seen, I recommend it to everyone who likes the genre.
reviews.heading: Impresses in multiple spots

reviews.content: I loved every minute of this movie. It was my favorite for maybe ten years.It combined 40s film noir, a classic detective thriller, complete with profound moral dilemmas. And it raises existential questions. How do we know we are really human? Love the line "More human than human," the motto of the company that made the androids and the theme of the movie itself. But the remake, "Blade Runner 2049" was horrible, one of the worst, most boring movies I have ever seen. What a waste of time.
reviews.heading: ONE OF MY FAVES

reviews.content: Watched this movie with high expectations, but it did not deliver. The movie overall was very slow, and kind of all over the place. Hard to understand the acting was good and so were the visual effects but it put me to sleep.
reviews.heading: Slow and confusing

reviews.content: Blade Runner is an altogether good film. The cast performs decently well, highlighted by Ford's sometimes intriguing role. Unfortunately, not much character development occurs just as the themes are not satisfactorily explored. The plot does set up understandable motivations for the characters, yet fails to create much of a convincing emotional depth out of them. Relationships between characters are largely overlooked, as well. Ford's lead role is absolutely the most intriguing and best character of the feature, but even he lacks an entirely distinct personality that could make the audience latch onto his fate. This makes the created tension, and therefore all the action, feel lesser than it should be. Although there are solid visuals and interesting set designs throughout, they surprisingly do not play much into the fight choreography, which takes place in more darkness than not. World building is solidly achieved, but there is ultimately much left desired in this small feel, slowly paced feature. There is a good score which compliments many scenes, though. Additionally, the central theme is intriguing and provides for a solid bookend to the plot due to last second dialogue. Overall, everything is mostly average and really nothing more aside from the visuals and some designs. Still, Blade Runner is worth a watch in spite of these flaws, especially for fans of the dystopian genre.
reviews.heading: A solid feature

reviews.content: On account of the film's 40 year anniversary this year, I just watched Blade Runner for the first time ever, after having intended to for years. Amongst many feelings, one thing seems obvious to me: it did not live up to my hype. Perhaps that is the hype's fault though more than the film?Visually, it's everything I had hoped for and more, it looks incredible and I never expected a 1982 sci-fi film could feel so modern and like it aged so well 40 years later. All sci-fi-films from this era usually have their fair share of very cringy, incredibly outdated "special effects moments" (even Star Wars is no exception) but save for some minor details Blade Runner really does feel like a film made just a few years ago, or maybe this year. Almost. It's like every synthwave/retrowave art ever made has exclusively used Blade Runner for reference and no other sci-fi. That's why it's such a shame that neither the story nor the characters are anywhere near as interesting.Perhaps I am indeed one of the many people "Blade Runner's" more vocal fans claim just "doesn't get it", and I'm perfectly open to accepting that, but one thing I am not is a contrarian just for the sake of being a contrarian. I simply cannot look past the vapid excuse of a script in this film, nor the wooden acting. And yes, I know that a significant amount of the film's cast are replicants and therefore you might say this rigidity could well be expected, but when Roy towards the end of the film suddenly is anything but wooden but instead very animated (howling like a wolf no less, for some reason) it isn't any better. It is in fact even worse. Not to mention outright laughable scenes like Roy "entering" headfirst through a wall, or another replicant conveniently not making use of her 100 %, clear-as-day opportunity to kill Deckard in favour of making herself a perfect target and be killed. The last 15-20 minutes of the film were quite different from the tone of the rest of the film, but it's not for the better, it feels odd and disjointed.I get the themes of the film and the points it's trying to convey, at least I'd like to think I do. And they are interesting, important points to ponder (albeit ones seen in plenty of other fiction; it is of course important to remember it was less so when the film originally came out) but the execution could have been and should have been leagues better if more time and effort had been spent in this area rather than the visual, cinematographic department.There isn't really anything inherently wrong with the story, just with the execution of it and ABOVE ALL the (non-existant) pacing. I did like that the film, for a good chunk of it's runtime, was not an action film, I thought that felt fresh especially for an 80s sci-fi picture and I feel like criticism about the film having too little action misses the entire point of "Blade Runner". It is, then, not so much that the lack of action is boring as it is that the lack of depth or motivations of the characters is boring.I gave this film a 7/10, but that is a generous score not based very much on the substance of the film itself. Rather, I just can't help but swoon over the gorgeous retrofuturistic visuals (which of course in 1982 were simply "futuristic") and Vangelis' soundtrack, even if I thought that the music could have benefitted from being less quiet, and less in the background. In the end, the end result is a mixed bag and whether or not people will enjoy this film is entirely based on what you're looking to get out of it. Blade Runner is fantastic as a retroactive display of the neo-noir sci-fi of the 80s that has become an appreciated aesthetic and subculture in modern times, but as a film? I'm not so sure.
reviews.heading: A matter of perspective

reviews.content: Yawning, that is what this movie will make you do. It's slow, it's boring, and I don't understand how it got an 8/10 because it is just bad. I would of had more fun counting sheep.
reviews.heading: Yawn

reviews.content:
There are two versions of this film which need review.First the theatrical release has been maligned because
of Harrison Ford's narration. If Deckard was a replicant
himself, his narration would be dispassionate anyway.Second, if he is retiring replicants as a Blade Runner,
he will not be emotional, it would likewise dispassionate.Also, I think the original Soundtrack for the movie was
great and have the audio cd.Second, it was apparent that Deckard fell for Rachel,
and the escape north along the coast to avoid his former
bosses made sense in the plot. The Final Cut version
doesn't make sense. My vote would be for the theatrical
release over the Final Cut except for certain corrections
in technical terms.Lastly, see both versions and make up your own minds.
reviews.heading: The Final Cut is bogus >>>>

reviews.content: Blade Runner is still holds up 40 years later. Despite the hilarious video phone booths, the 2019 futuristic setting feels real. The movie starts off slow but the scenes always give something interesting to look at. The replicants are very well acted, supporting themes about where the line between AI and human is drawn. To and perspective viewer, my only suggestion is that you stick through lulls because you will be rewarded greatly for it. To those keen audience members, there is symbolism and metaphor abound if you can spot it. All in all, a classic and definite watch.
reviews.heading: The Pinnacle of Noir

reviews.content: I was ten years old when Blade Runner came out and it played theaters so briefly in my small hometown that I never got the chance to see it. Also, ten year olds didn't get to see R rated films in 1982. So my first experience was reading the Archie Goodwin/Al Williamson Marvel Comics adaption, a book of which I literally read until the cover came off.I must have read this issue a thousand times.Steranko cover!I also asked my uncle, a librarian, for a copy of Philip K. DIck's Do Androids Dream of Electronic Sheep? Perhaps a ten-year-old was not yet ready for the complexity of Phillip K. Dick, but he never dumbed it down for me.The first time I finally saw Blade Runner on HBO it was after a year of reading about the film in Starlog, obsessing over the comic book and the source novel, so my experience was so alien to anyone else that saw it in theaters in 1982.For a movie seen as a failure - it made $41.6 million on a $30 million budget, so I have no idea how that is failure - this is a movie that literally changed the world and has grown to become our world.And yet, this is a movie that has seven different versions thanks to all of the changes from studio executives. Even the voiceover, which was added by them, has star Harrison Ford reading the words as if he has no interest, perhaps hoping if they were bad they'd never be used.The blade runner is former police officer Rick Deckard (Ford), who is charged by Gaff (Edward James Olmos) and Bryant (M. Emmet Walsh) with doing what he does best: hunting down robotic humanoids and retiring them. Now, he must stop four Nexus-6 replicants: Leon Kowalski (Brion James), Zhora Salome (Joanna Cassidy), Pris (Daryl Hannah) and Roy Batty (Rutger Hauer).Yet within this film noir story set in a neon-filled future straight out of a Moebius drawing, the real tale is about whether Rick and his lover Rachael (Sean Young) are humans or machines themselves. In fact, of all the characters, Batty is the most human of them all, a character of both deep menace and surprising tender thoughts.Blade Runner arises from pain. Ridley Scott had left Dune and lost his brother in short order and wanted something to take his mind off life. Dick had no idea it was even being made, but his initial distrust was saved somewhat when he saw the script revisions and special effects footage. Ford and Scott also fought throughout.Neither can agree if Deckard is human or replicant, even if they've made up.I think about Blade Runner a lot. I think about Pris flipping across the room, how her face paint looks, how deadly these killing machines are with such grace. I think of Rutger Hauer ad-libbing "All those moments will be lost in time...like tears in rain" and caressing the dove. I remember the spinner police car and Deckard's car that I had as a kid and played with constantly. And I wonder, does Gaff leave the silver unicorn after not killing Rachael as him telling Deckard to pursue his dream or is Deckard's dream of the unicorn just one progammed into him?Most of all, I'm so thankful for this movie because without it, I may not be so fascinated by Philip K. Dick, a person who I quote or reference every day. My uncle knew what he was doing.
reviews.heading: Incredible

reviews.content: As I did not see this movie in its prime but did see Blade Runner 2049 in theatres before ever seeing the first film it could play a factor in my opinion. Now the version I saw was The Final Cut I haven't seen the theatrical release or directors cut version. However the film story seemed very straight forward A Blade Runner must kill all Replicants and as a Detective essentially he goes about his assignment. I am not a Harrison Ford fan by any means I like Star Wars & Indiana Jones but this was a solid performance from Forward. He definitely captures the character very well.However I felt even for a under 2 hour movie this felt like a dull drag. I was intrigued at first and then slowly it began to kind of drag on and I felt somewhat losing interest. I am a huge fan of indie films and strange films but this film just didnt vibe with me.When the we get to the final act and the final face off if you will the way The Final Cut decides to wrap up felt so underwhelming. I do not always need an epic action filled ending but the way this wraps up just left me with "That's it?".The pros of this film is Fords performance and the special effects for its time was seriously impressive. The world they take into gives you typical film noir with a sci-fi flare. The world itself feels like a character on its own. But ultimately the delivery, pacing, and story just does not meet the expectations especially with the hype and fan base behind this film. Again I couldve been because I watched Blade Runner 2049 first, I waited too long to see it, or maybe I watched the wrong version for myself. But I wasn't entertained enough to watch the other 2 versions to find out.
reviews.heading: Not What I was Expecting

reviews.content: I don't get the hype for this movie. I thought I'd like it because I enjoy Harrison Ford, but this...I think was about to leave it as unfinished but with 30 min left, I figured I could suffer just a little bit longer. I get it was made in the 80s, so I can't be too harsh when it comes to special effects. Hell, the special effects weren't even my issue with it. The story sounded like it could be good. But everything else - between dialogue, action scenes, and pacing - were just terrible. It took me about two days to watch it because I kept having to stop it to take a break from it and do something else. I figured with as bad as it was it was probably directed by some no name director. Then I found out it was directed by Ridley Scott. I would've given the movie a 1/10, but because I like Harrison Ford, I figured that earned the movie 1 star, so I gave it 2/10.
reviews.heading: Boring

reviews.content: Blade Runner is a philosophical journey into a sci-fi underworld, steeped in rain, darkness and philosophy.I consider the 80's-90's the science fiction revolution - advances in technology and computers, along with the formation of major studios such as Lucasfilm gave us films like Alien, TRON, The Terminator, Star Wars, Dune, Brazil, The Fifth Element, I could go on. But among them is Blade Runner, a film that completely flopped upon its first release, but is now worshipped both in and out of film circles as a classic of the neo-noir genre.There's a very specific reason I simply adore Blade Runner so much - its vision of the future. Well, the future at the time - I am writing this review in 2022, meaning that according to Blade Runner, "the future" was three years ago. Either way, in a genre that's usually filled with colourful fantasy, Blade Runner is as noir as they get - mysteries that need solving, dark skyscrapers at night, rain, violence, all wrapped with a wonderfully-executed dose of brain-bending existentialism that makes us wonder what being human means.The film's pacing is languid, and I've noticed that brought up a lot. I mean, in general, I wouldn't say that this is the easiest film to love. The first time I saw it a few years ago, I had no idea what was going on, the storyline confused me, and the slowness of everything really didn't help. But upon a recent rewatch, that slowness is what really leaves time to appreciate the film in and of itself. Honestly, I feel like the miniature skyscraper shots could have an entire separate film dedicated to them, and Vangelis's soundtrack is probably my favourite piece of film music of all time. I guess that Blade Runner really is a bit of an acquired taste.Speaking of the visual effects, I don't think I'll ever stop praising them. I miss old science fiction, back when visual effects were hand-crafted and took care and time, as opposed to now, when everything has been replaced by computer renders and green screen. And honestly, the miniatures in this look better than half of the commercial green-screen garbage that we get nowadays anyway. I wish science fiction could go back to a simpler time.I watched the Final Cut, so I don't know what it's like with the voiceover or the "happy ending", but I'm honestly kind of glad that I don't. I enjoy the way that Ridley Scott's final vision throws us into this world of darkness with no explanation, and I like that ambiguous ending that keeps you wondering.In conclusion, even though I do agree that appreciation of a film such as Blade Runner is acquired, it's definitely a must-see science fiction classic.-Sasha.
reviews.heading: Neo-noir meets science fiction in a classic of both genres.

reviews.content: I'm 52 and this is first, and only time I will watch it. Was 12 when this "Master Piece" came out. The story didn't any flow to it. It just jumped around too much. I was hoping that it would get better as it went along, but it didn't. 4/10.
reviews.heading: Can't understand the 8+ review?

reviews.content:
I have seen this on various platforms over the years, and I always like the first 10 minutes because its so artfully done, (Ridley scott is really the world best set designer).So I watch the first 10 minutes and of course this ends up being the whole movie. This has happened 20 or 30 times....... Every viewing uncovers something new, The rough made cigarettes, how elaborate the background architecture is, how goofy the flying cars are. Using LA street punks as extras, Etc
This film made 8 careers Hauer,Sean Young,Olmos,Hannah, Brion James,Joanna Cassidy etc
It is masterly in its pacing, singular in its genre crossover and altogether one of my all time favorite films.
reviews.heading: Its Unique

reviews.content: I just watched Blade Runner for the first time, and I thought it was an amazing film, Ridley Scott is an incredible director, making such beloved classics such as Alien and The Martian, but this is his best film in my eyes, Blade Runner is simply brilliant and does everything a sci-fi movie should.It is an incredible looking and directed film, the visuals are superb and every shot is beautifully filmed, with masterful action and a fantastic story, it's dark and intelligent all while being compelling and poignant, with one of the best musical scores I've ever heard in my life, Harrison Ford is fantastic in this movie but Sean Young and Rutger Hauer compliment him incredibly, and it's also kind of hilarious at timesMultiple viewings are required for this sci-fi masterpiece, this is Ridley Scott's best film, and I'm gonna give it an A+
reviews.heading: Quite the experience

reviews.content: At first I thought that people who were giving this an 8-10 star review were just doing it out of nostalgia. But even the younger demographic is giving this utter waste of time high marks. I just don't get it. I haven't watch a film this awful in years. I haven't written a review in years... but I just had to do something to give that two hour experience some meaning. Dear God, it was painful!
reviews.heading: A Painful Experience

reviews.content: Innovative visuals for its time! An innovative concept that differs from the typical mechanical robot stories of sentience and servitude. This is about humans creating essentially "humans" which are virtually indistinguishable from their creators, however humans essentially treat them as slaves :-(
reviews.heading: Classic sci-fi movie! :-)

reviews.content: After a lifetime of drinking in echoes of this film from every conceivable angle it's genuinely deeply hard to watch it and separate it from all the cultural baggage. It feels like nothing more than a slightly existential spin on a 1940's noir (with no change to the grim sexual politics) set in a bewilderingly complex and stylised dystopian future that still feels fresh and vibrant. It still feels like something beamed directly from another time which is a remarkable feat - I can see why it has the influence it does but quite honestly more than anything I was just psyched to see a young EB from Deadwood. Nice.

reviews.content: I need to say that i enjoyed the movie. It have fascinating visuals, a very good sound design and some great special effects. The movie also have a great environnment design. That make the whole thing pretty pleasant to watch even in 2022. The story line is pretty classsic but what is original about it its the whole universe (Replicant, blade runner). I enjoyed it anyway and recommend the movie for the atmosphere and if he will succeed to find all replicants. Nice movie.

Every last second of the film - sets the standard. Everyone in this movie excels - it's just a cinema at its best!

reviews.content: An incredible, atmospheric and unique mystery/thriller, with an amazing setting, complemented by stunning cinematography and ethreal score.The world-building is ambitious, yet grounded, giving it a sense of realism, and the perfect blend of cgi with stunning visuals certainly helps. This makes the film incredibly engaging, even when the plot is unfolding very slowly. Even though it's sci-fi, the world feels very real and lived-in.The performances by the cast also makes the story of the film very impactful, helping to portray the themes explored in this film, such as 'What it really means to be alive?', in a much more enaging way.The plot, even though much simpler than expected, unfolds in the perfect manner and pace, mostly due to great directing by Ridley Scott.
reviews.heading: The Perfect SciFi-Dystopian mystery-thriller.

The atmosphere is well built, the soundtrack is simply so beautiful and gives such a sad vibe and works perfectly with the city landscape. AAAND is full of quotes. A must watch.

reviews.content: This movie is the definition of a slow burn. It's a simple plot rolled into a complex world that you're consistently learning more about from the first scene to the last. The aesthetic, the tone, the story, the acting, all of these things create a vision of Earth that has been left behind and forgotten. If you haven't seen Blade Runner, you're missing out on classic existential science fiction.

reviews.content: Great movie still holds up well today. Cinematography top notch, acting amazing from whole cast, directing on point, casting fantastic. Couldn't ask for anything better.

reviews.heading: over rated

reviews.content: Wow, what a film. First of all, the acting in this film is great. Rutger Hauer masterfully and emotionally gives off one of the greatest performances in cinema, his final monologue in the ending is so emotional and compelling. His facial acting is also great. We cannot also forget about Harrison Ford who also gives one of his best performances, playing the officer Rick Deckard, and also has some great line delivery and facial acting which makes for an emotional and powerful performance in my opinion. Also, the cinematography and directing and set design in this film is beautiful. This is Ridley Scott's most beautiful film by far, and almost every shot looks like a painting with the beautiful long shots of this horrible dystopian world. The script is also incredibly layered and complex, and has so much secrets like the unicorn and much more, which I won't get into since there is too much interpretations of this film. The film is incredibly philosophical with some great questions like, what makes a human human and much more questions about the human condition. Also the ending is beautiful and incredibly complex and can be interpreted multiple ways. The techno score is also great by the master Vangelis. Anyways, this film is a surreal, dreamlike masterpiece with beautiful cinematography, complex characters, an incredibly layered and complex script, great direction, and incredible acting. 9/10.
reviews.heading: A surreal, dreamlike sci-fi masterpiece.

reviews.content: Blade Runner describes a future in which, through genetics, artificial humans are manufactured and called "replicants"; employees in dangerous jobs and slaves in the outer colonies of the Earth. Made by Tyrell Corporation under the motto "more humans than humans" -especially the "Nexus-6" models- not only resembles humans, they are far superior physically.The replicants were declared illegal on planet Earth after a bloody mutiny occurred on the planet Mars, where they worked as slaves. A special police force, Blade Runners, is in charge of identifying, tracking and killing - or "withdrawing", in terms of the police itself - the fugitive replicants found on Earth. With a group of replicants loose in Los Angeles, Rick Deckard, the best agent that has existed in regard to the recovery and removal of the replicas, is removed from his semi-retirement to use some of "the old magic blade runner".Ridley Scott style and futuristic design is so well made that accomplished to create a visual vocabulary: neon lights, abandonment, decay, loneliness, obscurity, indifference and alienation are the core of the aesthetics of the film, which will eventually become and serve as a pattern for successive cinematographic works.
reviews.heading: Fantastic cyberpunk style

reviews.content: Haste is needed only when catching fleas.I said this to myself when I realized what to write a review about, but at the last moment I reread the plot of the continuation of the film from 2017. I watched it this year, but as it turned out, its plot is much more complicated, coupled with the first movie I watched. Much. And now I have a lot in my head.I liked the atmosphere of the city, always rainy, not sleeping, always at night, dirty, piled up with "fashionably" dressed people, cars, cafes, eateries, burning signs. The atmosphere of sin city.I am impressed by such main characters, independent, strong, detached from reality, but without losing emotions, serious, intelligent, purposeful, a little sad, instantly falling asleep after a hard day and a drop of hot stuff.There is such an idea that our entire environment: buildings, bridges, roads now look exactly like this, because 20-30 years ago we imagined it all this way. Do we now imagine what everything will look like in the future? Will we live in the same atmosphere? When will the decline of human culture come? And it is already inevitable. Instead of constantly burning signs, mobile phone screens, instead of boots and trousers, trousers tucked into high boots, oversized clothes, indifference to others, cruelty, drugs, alcohol. And the same night in the showers. And the same eternal rain.
reviews.heading: Haste is needed only when catching fleas.

reviews.content: I probably saw this way too young. We rented a laserdisc machine and this movie. I was scared but totally mesmerized. Now much older, I've seen this more times than I can count and always turn it on once a year on one of those long winter Sundays. One of the most immersive movies that always takes me back to my childhood. Fantastic movie that my kids now enjoy too. I didn't put any spoilers in this. Just watch and enjoy.

reviews.content: Blade Runner is stunning. It is one of the most beautiful films ever made. It has a great story, great performances, terrific action and eventually leaves a solid impact. I have seen the final cut, and I really liked it. Despite the very slow pace, I could actually enjoy the film and get amazed at this high-quality filmmaking.This film isn't fast-paced and doesn't simply jump to the main story within minutes. The first half sets up the characters and conflict, eventually followed by well-executed action sequences and intriguing character drama along with some really good twists. The rainy weather seemed to work for me. Most of the film happens at night, thus creating its own stylish atmosphere.Harrison Ford plays his part brilliantly and so does Rutger Hauer.There's a good amount of intensity that makes it a very intriguing watch. Blade Runner is undoubtedly one of the best sci-fi action movies of all time, also because it portrays 2019 in a realistic way.

reviews.content: This movie has truly stood the test of time and should be mandatory study for anyone working in the movie business.Every frame looks like a wall poster.Every song sounds like part of an album.Every storyline item feels like part of a series.A true masterpiece.

reviews.content: A sci/fi classic about human-like robots called replicants coming to earth to find their creator to extend their life span and it's up to a retired blade runner to come out of retirement to hunt them down. This is a film which is set in a dystopian future in Los Angeles. reviews.content: The special effects of the period are discomforting, as is the excess of darkness.Also disturbing is the vision of the future, apparently also of the time, predicting a kind of chaos, composed of elements such as disorderly crowds, lack of cleanliness, light and structures, as if living not as a cummunity, but as a huddle of selfish individuals seeking to survive.I may be ignorant or inattentive, but the replicants did not seem consistent with the context. Starting from the idea of machines with specific tasks, the replicants had too human behaviors, involving a lot of emotions, longings and relfections about themselves that have no origin in the story, leaving them free to the thorization of whoever is interested in them.

I am speechless! How come I never heard of this movie until now....12/23/21! I only knew it because of South Park post COVID special! This is one of the best movies i have watched in the last few years....
the story about the dystopic future we are all expecting to happen;the acting...Harrison Ford is truly a legend, I had an impression he has a general theme of acting that he used in Star wars, Indiana Jones but no, he was something different here, he his acting added a lot to the movie. Rutger Hager, what an actor! Sean Young... the acting in this movie is 10/10The director, is an artist, this movie is just beautiful to watch. This movie is well made, despite most old sci-fi movies usually look 'lame' and their cinematic tricks look outdated, this movie never felt anything like it.Last but not least, the mesmerizing music! This movie has one of the most beautiful soundtracks you can imagine, I MEAN IT, I am not exaggerating at all... went all over the internet to learn about the composer, Vangelis is the name...Haven't gave a 10 in over 3 years but this movie is something else...WOW.
