reviews.content:
I have to admit that I generally dislike Ridley Scott's style, but this movie was so well rated that I decided to give it a fair shot and watch it without prejudice. And I can say it is objectively lame.The theme is so good, which is why noone should have allowed Scoot to go near it. His childish approach to directing (seconded only by Michael Bay) ruined what could have been a great film, or even a saga. An entire "film universe" could have been build around replicants, similarly to what X-men have become. Instead, Scott pooped out this short, rushed, flawed film without any depth or character development.Alien was an okay film, because the theme is super simple and shallow - one ship, one crew, an alien. That's it. Not even Scott could mess that up too badly, especially when Sigourney Weaver carried his ass. In Blade Runner, there was nothing to stop Scott from botching the theme.Notes:
I was pleasantly surprised by how the visual effects hold up in 2021. However, the thriller/action scenes suffer from bad cuts and overall bad directing, which is the actual reason they are lackluster.Was there no controversy about the scene where Ford rapes that replicant? I was shocked when I watched it and thought almost everyone else had been, but to my surprise I didn't find any outrage. I understand 1982 were "different times" as sexual predators might put it these days. That's why I'm not asking why everyone in the movie smokes ALL the time. But rape was illegal and comndemnable even back then, so I really don't get it.
reviews.heading: Ridley Scott didn't disappoint in that he did disappoint again.

reviews.content:
Let me first say that I indeed have understood the movie and the message of it. I understand the questioning of humanity and our nature.When I first read about this movie I thought and still am thinking , that the idea of the movie is quite unique and interesting. However ,
I was expecting kind of a detective hunt for replicans but instead got an incredibly slow , boring , dramatic , lifeless , bland looking movie.Harrison Ford had like 20 lines so don't expect to care even a slight about this guy. I honestly couldn't care for a second if he dies . I dont need a movie to be an action movie but It just didn't do anything to glue me to the screen.One Replican women fights Harrison Ford for 3 seconds , decides to make 4 flips and dies. What kind of replican was she ? Ballerina or something !?I guess we were supposed to be in some way invested in a love relationship that our main character has. Except that is shown for 2 minutes . The freaking Coca Cola bilboard has more run time in this movie than that.The only thing that made this movie watchable was the ending. It had deeper message that makes you think about us humans in general.I just don't see how anyone can say this movie is thrilling. Maybe if you have seen 2 movies in your lifetime , you might say that because i can name comedy movies that were more thrilling than this one.I wish I could say more positive things. I liked what this movie tried to tell but the way it tried to do that was like a math teacher talking about mathematical diagrams. I am sure some like it , I am sure it is useful but you will probably be bored out of your mind before something interesting comes up.Just like this movie.6/10Platinuman.

reviews.content: Note: this review is of the 2007 "Final Cut" of the film, which is the one that director Ridley Scott was given full creative control over. It is considered by many fans, including myself, to be the definitive version of the film. It is also the most widely available version nowadays and hence it is the version that I recommend to seek out and watch."Blade Runner" mixes classical noir cinema with a sleek cyberpunk Japanese anime-inspired aesthetic. The cinematography is what makes this movie shine to me. Every shot, angle, lighting, is mesmerizing to witness. Harrison Ford does a great job as the blade runner agent, Deckard, as well.It was kind of a bomb when it came out, but I attribute that to audiences not really understanding what it was and poor marketing for the film. It's also R-rated, which normally affects a movie's performance as well. The large budget and some sci-fi action scenes shown in marketing steered a lot of people into wrong perceptions of the movie and critics thus wrote it off as slow and boring. It is first and foremost a noir crime mystery, much more in the vein of something like "Chinatown" than "Star Wars."The plot and themes of this movie can't be ignored either. Our story centers around a group of agents known as "blade runners", whose job is to track down and "retire" android human replicants because they become rebellious and unreliable at a certain stage in their life cycle. A few rogue replicants have returned to earth and murdered a blade runner, so it is Deckard's job to find them and eliminate them. Throughout the movie, we are questioned about the very things that make us human.Timeless and classic, this movie stands as a marvel of cinema and a true testament to the fact that sci-fi as a genre can help us isolate our problems as a species; to put them in a hypothetical realm of fiction and analyze them without malice or prejudice. The gritty noir crime mystery style marries excellently with that. I recommend this movie to just about anybody who likes these types of deep philosophical stories.
reviews.heading: Man or Machine?

reviews.content: This is a slow moving, boring movie. I saw it in the 1980s and was bored then. I thought maybe I was too you (11 or 12) at the time to understand it. Well, I watched it again nearly 40 years later and was still bored nearly to tears. There are some redeeming aspects - Harrison Ford is all Harrison Fordy in a good way and a young Daryl Hannah gives a nice performance.
reviews.heading: I don't get what all the fuss is about.

reviews.content: David Peoples (12 Monkeys) one of my favorite screenwriters does an excellent adaptation of the Phillip K. Dick novel, Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep. Not only that, Rutger Hauer who stars as a genetically engineered slave, creates the best line in the whole movie - one of my favorite lines from any movie.This is the only movie I've seen where we are made to follow around the protagonist, only to realize that he's the bad guy (a cold killer who drowns his emotions in booze and strong arms a genetically engineered female, who is probably only a few years old, into kissing him). And the people presented as antagonists, turn out to be escaped slaves coming back to earth to kill members of the slave trade. The movie doesn't rub the slaves' plight in your face though, the way a Tarantino movie would. There is no poppy 60s rock hit playing while the killing happens. Killing is treated seriously no matter who dies. And because of this it took me several viewings to realize the obvious. I have seen many YouTube reviews done by very good film critics who even miss this point. They complain that the good guy shouldn't be drinking and molesting up the neighborhood. But he's NOT the good guy. Sheesh. The good guy is the escaped slave - not the bad cop.Anyways.There have been many versions, I think my favorite is the late 90s director's cut because it has warmer colors than other versions. The art from Moebius' work, adapted by Syd Mead, is classic too.
reviews.heading: Bad Cop Hunts Down Escaped Slaves

reviews.heading: Many Films Are Called A Masterpiece

reviews.content:
For a movie made in1982, i think its a good one for that time.To see it in 2021, its laughable. It has so many goofs, chaotic scenes, plot holes, scene pieces filmed in different times and glued together that
today this movie wouldn't even hit DVD release in this state. It looks made by a school kid as a summer project.Was interesting to see how they imagined world 40 years later. With a few things, they were spot on.
reviews.heading: Its hard to rate a 40 yo movie

reviews.content: The glimpse of our future ; for the pure subject to have reflection is for it to automatically realise, nihilistically, that consciousness is itself nothing. Unless this happens, the replicant remains a "simpersonator", able to simulate personalities, but always confusing personality-function with consciousness-as-essence. In other words, unlike Deckard, the pure subject would not go from "it does not know what it is" to "it now knows what it is", but from "it does not know what it is" to "it knows it cannot know what it is becoming", which is the kind of morbidly fked up place Cronenberg now resides. But, philosophically, "Blade Runner" doesn't go this extra mile. If the film is about nostalgia and loss, it remains trapped on the level of thinking in terms of "memories" and "death". IE - whether replicant or human, memories aren't ours and all existence ends in death, as bemoaned by one dying, rain-drenched replicant. In this regard, the film is a lamentation more in the style of such Westerns as "Once Upon A Time In The West", "Unforgiven" and "The Wild Bunch". Indeed, "Blade Runner's" screenwriter, David Peoples, injects many western motifs into the film, borrows heavily from "High Noon" (a 1952 western that features a lone bounty hunter tasked with killing four outlaws) and would himself go on to write "Unforgiven". Fused with these are director Ridley Scott's motifs - an emphasis on eyes, photographs, pictures etc - (photographs are objects of place, sentiment, history, and memory. Similarly, phrases like "we get the picture" or "world picture" show that consciousness can be discussed in terms of a picture) all of which stress the recording and capturing of memories.
reviews.heading: The glimpse of our future

reviews.content: Not good. No flow or mood. Main character talks for about 2% of the film. Boring and such a slow and unfufilling development. Villian was ok. Good concept. Really cool world. Movie is weird doesnt really make sense.
reviews.heading: Very Over-Rated

reviews.content: I love that this movie inspired waves of sci-fi themes and tropes to follow. It's like reading a foundational text, in that you feel you're doing something important, something scholarly, and at the same time you are bored out of your mind. I struggled to stay awake during this movie. Keep in mind I watched the Final Cut edition, as I could not find the original anywhere, but so many scenes were absolutely unengaging. I was unsure what genre I was in because of how slow the story moved at some points. Not to mention, that scene with Rachael was quite rapey. Did not come off well. I did not expect this movie to be one where the moment you lose focus for more than 30 seconds, the story makes no sense henceforth. It's hard to follow and its reputation did not prepare me for that.
reviews.heading: BORED!

reviews.content: I thought watching this film in 2021, a film made in 1982 wouldn't stand up, but this one really did! The makeup and the graphics and surprisingly on point for such an old film and I was pleasantly surprised. Film keeps you interested and I enjoyed the concept. Definitely worth a watch.
reviews.heading: Really enjoyed this film

reviews.content: Blade Runner (1982) movie reviewRated: M for Science Fiction ViolenceRelease Date: 10 July 1982 (Theatrical Cut), 19 December 2007 (Final Cut)The Main Storyline: Rick Deckard, an ex-policeman, becomes a special agent with a mission to exterminate a group of violent androids. As he starts getting deeper into his mission, he questions his own identity.Ridley Scott (Director of Alien and Gladiator) did an awesome work on the cyberpunk movie based on the Phillip K. Dick novel "Do Androids Dream on the Electric Sheep?". Thanks to Ridley for the Final Cut Version of the Movie. Harrison Ford (from Star Wars and Indiana Jones) is the best Detective Character Rick Deckard in this movie. Also stars Sean Young as Rachel and Rutger Hauer as the Villain Roy Batty. It's a Live-Action Cyberpunk Movie. It's got Action, Sci-Fi and Thriller in it. I enjoyed watching the movie when I was 12 but it's really cool. Back in 2015, I watched it in cinemas but it's really classic. I love this Cyberpunk Movie because it's really awesome like The Matrix (1999), Alien (1979) and Prometheus (2012)Note: Please watch the Final Cut of the Movie, Not the other ones.I give it 10/10Thanks for ReadingThis movie is now streaming on Netflix. Now available on iTunes, Google Play, Blu-Ray and DVD.
reviews.heading: I love the Cyberpunk movie

reviews.content: My history with Blade Runner goes like... 1) disappointed and almost hated it, 2) appreciate but still don't really enjoy, and 3) I actually like it.Of course when first seeing it I expected action adventure like Star Wars and Indiana Jones and it wasn't anything like that. Only after seeing it several times along the years, the film's haunting and bleak atmosphere has started to appeal to me. At first I thought it's too depressing but a while ago I had this strange thought: "hmm... I miss that Blade Runner atmosphere, I should watch it again!" Then, a couple of days ago I found the blu ray (Final Cut) very cheap so I decided to pick it up.I've always liked the visuals of this movie. The amazing futuristic landscapes and neon light effects, it's all some of the best special effects in any movies ever.The story is a bit more complex thing. I'm not sure if I still entirely get the themes it deals with but I've started to like it anyway. But one thing I must say: it's not a very good movie to casually put playing when you want something fun to relax with. It's more like... when you are already in some special thoughtful mood, alone in the middle of the night, and want to get immersed in a strange world. The feeling I get from this movie is difficult to explain but it's like...being alone in the middle of...nothingness. At first it was depressing but now it has started to be fascinating and somehow comforting even.If you don't like the movie first time around, give it time, and maybe see later again.Ps. I watched the Final Cut version but I don't really know what's different abot it because it's been a while since I saw some other version.
reviews.heading: Visually amazing sci-fi classic is a slow grower

reviews.content: We are doomed to roam space in the medium to long term future. This will take us far in our daydreams as a colonizing species, even more so than we have done in recent centuries, much more. The creation of anthropomorphic entities will be a reality. What no one is fully sure of is whether they will be partially human and cyborgs or hybrids, fully machines or assorted groups of them as has already been seen in human imagery or science fiction.The human being, thanks to his advances, will one day become a "superior human". As Euripides, then Confucius, and finally Nietzsche put it: a superior man. We know what there is between the animals and us, between us and the superior man we are still discovering it, but not between the superior human and God, since it is something hidden from our mind and we will only be able to observe those shadows on the wall of the Cavern from Plato with enthusiasm to profusion.This review should be read as such and understood as one more opinion. As a viewer, I promise to cite the elements that converge in the film in a pleasant way and as a whisper for the seatmate, skipping compliments and grievances.We are doomed to roam space in the medium to long term future. This will take us far in our daydreams as a colonizing species, even more so than we have done in recent centuries, much more. The creation of anthropomorphic entities will be a reality. What no one is fully sure of is whether they will be partially human and cyborgs or hybrids, fully machines or assorted groups of them as has already been seen in human imagery or science fiction.The human being, thanks to his advances, will one day become a "superior human". As Euripides, then Confucius, and finally Nietzsche put it: a superior man. We know what there is between the animals and us, between us and the superior man we are still discovering it, but not between the superior human and God, since it is something hidden from our mind and we will only be able to observe those shadows on the wall of the Cavern from Plato with enthusiasm to profusion.Starting from the Blade Runner as a specially trained special policeman for "El Retiro" of these Nexus 6 Replicator units that had revealed their status as "colonizing slaves", their existence is indisputable. The Nexus 6 Replicators are units by and for the colonization of other planets that, having been declared outlawed on Earth for disobeying and murdering in a rebellion or mutiny, in a sidereal colony, six males and three females (specifically, it was an assault on a shuttle space) against their higher command, they must be eliminated. They must, therefore, be sought, located and discarded in order to safeguard human lives, as they represent a real danger, due to their strength, as well as their intelligence.Power without control is useless. As we all know, Asimov's 'Three Laws' had been broken.The units of Blade Runner proceed throughout the film to the exhaustive persecution and execution of these "rebels" on the condition that we free ourselves from a possible war with the other replicants or depletion of the human species. All this offered by them; the Tyrell Corporation. It is obvious that this corporation is obliged to answer for its error in the programming of this Series of Nexus or Replicators.In identifying these, the V. K. test is used.Designed as copies of human beings in every way except their emotions; however, after a while they can develop their own emotional responses such as hatred, love, fear, anger, envy... For this reason and with this information in their hands, the Corporation decided to give them only four years of useful life.Offered the persecution by the Blade Runner Deckard, already against the end, which is a milestone in the cinema of the eighties: Roy Batty shows and makes the veteran Blade Runner understand what he believes it is to be a slave, making him go through the experience of fear of profusion. After saving Deckard's life, he will say several phrases that will startle the viewer and B. R. himself until they understand that what the Replicator wanted was to share his experience with someone who could understand him.Although, loneliness is here and in Orion, even at the Tannhäuser Gate, very, very annoying.In truth, playing to create beings that perfectly replicate the human species, artificial beings but indistinguishable from humans, is either a challenge or a daring of which in the future, we will have to respond.
reviews.heading: We are doomed

reviews.content: I can only really speak to the first 15 minutes or so, I'm sure it only gets worse. For some reason they decided to turn a story about a man who does things of questionable moral character finally having to examine the ethics of what he's doing into a stupid "they always pull me back in" story. Why is the owl explicitly artificial? It makes the owl mean nothing. Why is Rachael Rosen's android status so easily given up? Why did they skip the important part of the bearskin rug question(the bearskin rug)? Why is every character's name changed? Where is Mercer and Mercerism?(honestly maybe Mercerism is in this picture but I didn't stick around to find out)This picture is the same as its title: nothing, completely void of any meaning.
reviews.heading: Very bad picture, one of few I had to stop for being bad

reviews.content: Hard to add anything here that hasn't been expressed before. This is for me pretty much as close to perfection as film making gets.One of the joys of this film is that it exists in multiple versions that each bring something different. As a huge Noir fan I love the original version with the narration, but as a huge Sc-Fi fan, I love the darker tone of the director's cut. The workprint is interesting for its alternate dialogue/takes, especially the alternate rooftop shot of Batty, Deckard and the Spinner which is breathtaking! The Final Cut is probably my least favourite but it's at least interesting to see how Ridley Scott would ultimately like the film to be seen.From the gorgeous visuals to the stunning score, this is an absolute treat and what great cinema is all about!
reviews.heading: Like a Billy Wilder film on a Sci-Fi acid trip...outstanding!

reviews.content: Wish they had not made the so-called sequel and ruined the mystique.The world is in a state of post-apocalyptic darkness and the almond eyes have more or less taken over. A detective is tasked with tracking down dangerous artificial life forms who can only brings destruction on this world.Mystery, action, romance and science ensue. Above all the design of the sets and the world will blow you away.Wow.
reviews.heading: Excellent

reviews.content: I need a blade runner tv show, come on Amazon, Netflix's or HBO. I would like to see an expanded universe based on the blade runner franchise. If only we could band together and convince them to do a show.
reviews.heading: Need more!!

reviews.content: Plenty of cool elements, but I just don't get it really. Feel like it's more of a nostalgic watch if you enjoyed it in the day. Not big fan and don't watch it frequently or look to upgrade my BluRay to 4k or whatever will be next.
reviews.heading: Don't care for it

reviews.content: This is the most perfect movie I've ever seen.And here are my reasons:1) Impeccable storyline. Written to screenplay from the book flawlessly. If you REALLY pay attention to every scene (and for some it may take a few times to watch to "get it") then you'll fully grasp everything to make sure that everything makes sense and is followed up to a satisfying conclusion (and I'm referring to the "Final Cut" here). It's truly genius and WAY AHEAD OF ITS TIME.2) The haunting and iconic score by Vangelis is some of the best work done with a movie I've heard since John Williams or Danny Elfman (who came a bit later). You wanna talk about "nailed it"?! He NAILED. IT.3) The futuristic dystopian set design is so detailed that, even if it was supposed to be set in 2019 LA, has nothing to do with the weather. We're meant to explore a deeper world on the "inside"... whatever that means to you.4) We see a lot of familiar faces here but this was when a lot of the actors were still putting themselves on the map... and they absolutely succeeded.5) The dialogue is UNBELIEVABLE. And I mean that in the absolute BEST way. You are left with the perfect amount of hope and emptiness at the same time which is EXACTLY what Blade Runner was aiming for, I believe. Either way? Hats off."The light that burns twice as bright lasts half as long"... omg my jaw hit the floor with that one.Netflix picked up "Blade Runner: The Final Cut" recently and I could not control my excitement. This movie came out before I was even born and as I watch it to this day it still blows everything else out of the water that I've seen so far in terms of slow-burn, sci-fi, neo-noir... it's just absolute brilliance on screen from start to finish.Oh and btw - at about an hour and six minutes in while Deckard is looking back at Racheal, notice his eyes. He's definitely a replicant and if he's not... WOW. Way to leave imagination up in the air. I truly love it.Any time I ever return home from a long trip as well I always yell that special line in my head: "Home again, Home again... Jiggity Jig"Another great and if not perhaps the best line of all: "It's too bad she won't live... but then again, who does"...Without question: 10/10.
reviews.heading: To those that are watching this for the first time?! Prepare to think about it for YEARS.

reviews.content: This review contains spoilers.Blade Runner is a science fiction movie that premiered in 1982 and is directed by Ridley Scott. The movie is loosely based on Philip K. Dick's "Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?". A group of replicants have escaped to Earth and a grizzled veteran Blade Runner named Deckard is dispatched to hunt them down.Blade Runner is a movie with a simple plot. A Blade Runner, played by Harrison Ford, is dispatched to hunt down replicants. Deckard is forced to track down the replicants as well as deal with a contradictory world. The story is fine and serviceable for the movie to explore the interesting world and themes. Blade Runner is a dystopic world run by super corporations that have exceptions made for them.The replicants are used to explore the theme of humanity. As each of the replicants were made for a purpose, the replicants are essentially machines to humans and corporations. However as the story progresses, it becomes clear that the replicants have had fulfilling lives as they embark on one last quest to obtain more life. It is a simple goal, and the movie does this well. The replicants ironically have dreams whereas the human characters are stagnant and do not.Blade Runner is a gorgeous movie. This is a movie that still holds up in today's viewings. The computer generated imagery is dated, but the methods of showing it do not make the computer generated imagery seem fake. The movie prioritizes its characters instead of its visuals.There are many different cuts in this movie that are present on home video. The best cut I found was the final cut. The overall story in each of the cuts are not different. The main differences are how the themes are presented with the deleted scenes. The ending differs from cut to cut, but this only impacts the main character of Deckard. All of the different cuts have the same high quality as the theatrical movie.I highly recommend "Blade Runner".Grade: A.
reviews.heading: Dystopic Humanity

reviews.content: My teenage son and I watched this movie with high expectations. How disappointed we were. The story, or what passes for it, moves at such a glacial pace, with nothing much happening for most of the time, that we regularly checked our watches. It's difficult to follow what is happening, and why.Deckard seems to be some kind of anti-hero who bumbles and stumbles his way through his assignments. Without serious luck or having his life saved by replicants, he'd have died in each of the four encounters. We learn nothing about him that would make us identify with him, and it's hard to feel involved in or care for what he does.Yes, the visuals look great, but the movie seems to be inspired by seventies European art movies, in which dark and gloomy is mistaken for deep and meaningful. The visuals, combined with the slow pace, brooding humans and deranged replicants may have looked cool in 1982, but in 2021 it just comes across as pretentious and shallow.Every bit of meaning that people seem to project into the movie, they, well, project into it, presumably because it looks dark and gloomy. Plus the movie is sadistic. The violence is gory, and we hated it. It should come with an 18+ rating. I guess it's a new trick to first have a movie rated, and then later edit the gore back in.The scene in which Roy kills his maker is disgusting, and totally unnecessary. Roy is deranged and traumatized and mad with resentment and hates his maker for the limited life-span he's given. We get it. No need to actually show his sadistic handiwork. Unless you think sadistic violence is deep and meaningful of course. What rubbish.As an aside, watching this movie in 2021, it's amazing what people in 1982 thought was going to happen in nearly 40 years. Flying cars? Colonizing planets? No hint of something called the Internet? At least a ruined climate comes close to the mark.
reviews.heading: Pretentious, gory tosh

reviews.content: This movie is beautiful, the futuristic set and props are mind blowing good. The aesthetics are beautiful and the soundtrack is great and the story is very interesting, robots trying to be human. Very good movie definitely recommend.
reviews.heading: Amazing

reviews.content: A movie I didn't care for when it was released but became my favorite of all time over the years.
reviews.heading: Best Sci-fi of all time

reviews.content: Ridley Scott follows up the amazing Alien film with probably his best work overall in Blade Runner. Everything from the Phillip K. Dick novels to the classical Aristotelian and Socratic philosophies are on perfect display and presented in a digestible, but slightly obfuscated way that demands multiple viewings. Add in some great performances by Harrison Ford, Rutger Hauer, and Sean Young, and a very young Daryl Hannah as Pris, and with Scott's touch for set design and screenplay direction, creates a recipe for absolute success.A classic, 9/10.
reviews.heading: "I'm not in the business... I.. am the business"

reviews.content: I understand that the original US theatrical release had narration, making it even more noir-like. I watched the Director's Cut that has no narration. And while the director himself was unhappy with the narration in the theatrical release (even though he had originally intended for the film to have narration but later decided against it- prompting the studio to go over him and include it anyway), and while many have referred to narration as "spoon-feeding the audience" I actually think narration/voiceovers add another artistic layer to movies and makes them flow more elegantly much of the time. And depending on how well I like the narrator's voice, it can be like music and make the film much more beautiful. So, I wish the version I saw had narration, but I digress...According to my IMDb ratings, I've watched this film before, but apparently, it made such a bad impression on me then, that I wiped it from my memory (interesting how that sentence connects to the plot of the film itself, haha), because I had no idea going into it this time.Truth be known, I only watched it because Jane Wiedlin of The Go-Go's listed it as her #1 favorite movie. But, I did not like it and found it rather boring. It was devoid of any true lightness, humor, sensuality, or romance- which are sort of requirements for me to like a film. Not to mention, I didn't like the look or the score, which are also requirements for me.If you like very dark, gritty films with lots of action, not much music, and that are dangerous, ultra-serious, and long, then you will like this. But, if you like your action-thrillers a little more breezy, and with a cheeky quality, this isn't for you.I'd probably like the theatrical release better, as I'm a sucker for voice-overs and happy endings. But, probably not that much better. I just don't think this film is for me.
reviews.heading: I only watched it because Jane Wiedlin of The Go-Go's listed it as her #1 favorite movie.

reviews.content: Blade Runner has flaws such as the forced romance between Rachael and Deckard, the flow of the story being slowed down when ever Sebastian is in a scene but I don't care. I love this movie. The visuals, the music, the characters and best of all the world are crafted so perfectly. The world feels real. There is little stuff that you can miss in your first viewing, I missed stuff and on my second viewing I learned things about the world that made me think about the world, why is the world like that, why are replicants banned from earth.The things that bother me though are the Sebastian scenes, they really slow the movie down. It's the only part that feels like a dread to watch. He's just not interesting.But despite that this movie is beautiful.
reviews.heading: Blade Runner is a flawed masterpiece

reviews.content: I must be honest I had pretty high expectations for this one. No. 173 on IMDb is pretty high. But alas, I found it to be a little too confusing. While I get the point of the main plot, it was a little odd. Whereas the subplots just felt like it was an afterthought, with little depth or significance to the film. Though right when I was going to label it as a disappointment, it surprisingly turned around and the ending really made up for its earlier flaws. Overall it was a fairly enjoyable watch, but if you're looking for action, it will seem like a sore disappointment.
reviews.heading: Good, just not that good

reviews.content: This film, much like 2001 A SPACE ODYSSEY, has vexed me ever since childhood. I think one has to be over 40 to really appreciate what this movie has to offer, but it comes off as so narratively bland and straight-forward that I can't help but feel disappointed with every cut (and there are many).The opening couldn't be better. We get thrust into this dark horrible world of an overpopulated dystopian metropolis where it never seems to stop raining, advertisements bombard the populace, and flashing lights periodically invade every nook and cranny. The universe building and the special effects to accomplish it go off the chart in a way few other science fiction movies can achieve. On top of that, the world seems so realistic and lived-in that it's fascinating just to watch the people walk around and the cars float amongst the buildings.However, the plot lacks anything resembling a twist and just goes through the motions on autopilot. It's possibly a victim of the short story not supporting a full feature film, but even then there's a lot of good stuff in Philip K. Dick's original novella that got unfortunately cut. In some respects, I'll say that the recent late sequel works better as a narrative, but even that film has a lot of issues in other areas. For one, effects are no longer the awe inspiring show-stopper that they were back when this film was made.Blade Runner maintains some additional interest in that its villain and friends come off far more sympathetic than the hero. A lot gets left to the imagination, such as the fate of a few of the side characters. However, it spends too much time on the very dry relationship between a wooden Harrison Ford and a wooden Sean Young (though it works for her character). The two actually seem (from their tone and body language) to despise each other which doesn't really give us a lot to root for with them building a forbidden love. We also lose much sense of conflict with the hero "sort of" tasked with killing his own lover but he doesn't seem too pressured, either internally or from his superiors. It's an inhuman world but the movie needed a little more of a human heart to fully engage.A groundbreaking film in terms of world building and (like ALIEN and TERMINATOR) I'd love to see more films set in this universe, with the caveat that each film doesn't just follow the exact same formula as sequels tend to do.
reviews.heading: Excellent opening, effects, and production design undercut by blah characters.

reviews.content: I watched the sequel first, which blew my mind and became one of my most favorite movies. This one (the director's cut) was partly outstanding and partly disappointing to me. The brilliant, compelling scenography, the deep philosophical topics, the evocative sound, the amazing costumes and overall aesthetics are here, justifying it's fame. However, I found it to be overly dramatic, shallow and quite goofy at times, which I didn't see coming at all, having read the raving reviews.
reviews.heading: A flawed milestone for sci-fi noirs

reviews.content: While the directing, sets, effects, and various visual elements of the film were pleasant to experience, the plot could have been handled a bit better. This film is very unique for its time and style and while it has good performances it didn't really come together coherently for me.
reviews.heading: Not Harrison Ford's best film, but Ridley Scott never completely disappoints!

reviews.content: "Blade Runner" is a long time 80s classic film. The screenplay by Hampton Fancher and David Webb peoples is brilliant along with the depiction of the future as a cold, dark world.Harrison Ford portrays Rick Deckard. An ex policeman who is tasked to terminate dangerous androids (Replicants). Until he starts questioning his own identity.The movie in all aspects is terrific, it has action, dialogue and a lot of motives. I honestly don't have anything bad to say about this film. I have seen the director's cut so I loved it. I prefer in general endings who have a deeper meaning than the commercial Hollywood type of ending.
reviews.heading: One of Ridley Scott's Finest 8/10

reviews.content: What a shame for a movie that was undervalued at its time. Fortunately, over time its value was realized. An excellent movie.
reviews.heading: Cult

reviews.content: I've always considered Ridley Scott to be an overrated director, whose reputation rests largely on the success of two classic science fiction films, Alien and Blade Runner. But on the basis of those two, it is perhaps easy to understand the acclaim that they have brought him, and the latter - originally mangled by film studios and later attaining cult status - is arguably his masterpiece. 2007's 'The Final Cut' finally saw him exercising complete artistic control over it, and is likely to be regarded as the definitive version.The screenplay for Blade Runner by Hampton Fancher and David Peoples is very loosely based on Philip K. Dick's novel Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep? And is set in a neo-noir near-future (actually 2019) Los Angeles where a group of artificially synthesised Replicants go rogue and decide they want a shot at a normal human life, or at least a normal human lifespan. Harrison Ford's world-weary former detective turned "blade runner" Rick Deckard is tasked with hunting them down. The screenplay isn't particularly faithful to Dick's novel and in fact Deckard owes more to the gumshoes of Film Noir than he does to the original prose version, but the film is all the better for it; even Dick reportedly approved of the script and what little he saw of the film, which was released shortly after his death.So why has Blade Runner come to be regarded as such a classic example of film science fiction? For one thing, it is cerebral science fiction, which takes the themes of Dick's novel and brings them to the big screen, throwing in additional questions about what constitutes humanity; the ambiguity as to whether or not Deckard is a Replicant is something that the writers, director and cast disagree on and add to the film's enduring legacy. It also raises questions about identity, reflected in Rachael's ignorance of her Replicant nature due implanted memories. Zhora's slow-motion, agonised death raises the question of whether the Replicants really deserve to be hunted down like animals. The film offers only moral ambiguities: Leon and Roy are both killers, but then they have both been created as slaves and rebelled, as Roy notes during his philosophical final scene.For another, the look of the film, pre-digital and achieving using matte shots, model-work and set design, is astonishing and has had huge influence on science fiction ever since. The moody, rain-soaked future Los Angeles contributes as much to the feel of the story as any of the performances. Scott's Los Angeles is simultaneously seedy and exotic, hi-tech and run-down, and has inspired dozens of imitators. Vangelis score, which combines electronic and classical music, perfectly suits this visual aesthetic. The casting too is near-perfect, with minor roles taken and made memorable by the likes of Edward James Olmos, M. Emmet Walsh, James Hong and Joe Turkel. Ford portrays Deckard as a down-to-Earth everyman in a film filled with oddballs and eccentrics. Sean Young and Daryl Hannah play very different Replicants, the first vulnerable and initially unaware of her true nature, whose innocence proves seductive to Deckard, the second knowingly seductive and exploiting the fact to get close to the naïve and lonely J. F. Sebastian.Rutger Hauer gives the performance of his career as the terrifying, charismatic Roy Batty. Audiences weaned on more conventional science fiction films at the time might have been expecting a climatic final battle between him and Deckard, rather than the poignant and haunting climax that they got, as Roy saves Deckard's life and ends his own with a dignified monologue that has become one of cinema's most quoted. The ending (mangled on the film's original release by meddling studio executives with a hideous tacked on final scene recycling footage filmed for The Shining) is memorably fatalistic, as Deckard flees with Rachael only to be warned by an origami unicorn left by Gaff that nobody lives forever.Scott was reportedly reluctant at first to make Blade Runner, a film with a troubled gestation and one that took years to finally be appreciated in a form that the director was happy with. It is remarkable than that it remains one of the best science films ever made; it is even more remarkable that it took thirty-five years for anyone to make a sequel...
reviews.heading: Scott's masterpiece and one of the greatest science fiction films of all time

reviews.content: The similarities between the film and the Philip K. Dick novel are coincidental. If you read Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep you are bound to be disappointed that it is nothing like the film and you cannot imagine Harrison Ford as Rick Deckard.I admire the film more for its technical aspects and stunning visuals. I never had the opportunity to see this on a big screen. I imagine that it was something to behold. But the story itself is more or less just a routine cops and robbers scenario with some sci-fi dressings. When I first saw it it still had the much disliked voiceover narration by Harrison Ford. Many years later I saw one of the numerous alternate cuts which abandoned the narration. I found the film even more dull without it, but removing it from the final moments with Rutger Hauer was absolutely correct and gives the scene a deeper emotional impact as we project our own thoughts at what was happening. It is by far the best scene in the entire film.I am by no means the first person to suggest that the film would have been vastly improved had Rutger Hauer's Batty and the escaped androids been the central characters and Rick Deckard given slightly less screen time, especially the flat romance between him and Rachel (played by Sean Young). It takes up too much screen time and adds nothing of greater interest to the overall story. Both look like they are sleepwalking through their performances. The truly interesting characters are those androids in search of their creator in order to extend their limited lifespan. It is a theme se can all relate to. Just when we've gotten to understand our lives it's over, and all our memories are, as Batty so poignantly states, are lost in time like "tears in the rain". But these characters are far from noble or heroic and places us in a moral grey area and suggest the idea: How far would you go to extend your life. Batty, being an android, does not have these moral obstacles and will get to his objective by any means necessary. This could have been a truly thought-provoking film but if not for that final confrontation between Batty and Deckard it would be just an over produced police procedural. The music by Vangelis is quite haunting and adds to the otherworldly quality. The film visually arresting but emotionally empty. It was the first blu-ray I bought on account of those visuals, especially being the age before CGI effects. The miniature work is awesome.
reviews.heading: Style over substance

reviews.content: The picture is a triumph for Scott, who whallops over the "B. R." thesis and atmosphere with a strong sense of style, and relentlessness.
reviews.heading: A triumph for Scott

reviews.content: "Blade Runner" might have its flaws, but it is still the quintessential cyberpunk blockbuster. The undercooked love story and the goofy action sequences are the inevitable product of its time, but aesthetically it was miles ahead. I recently watched the director's cut 4K remaster and, hairstyles and old TV sets aside, it could almost pass as a fairly recent film. Ridley Scott goes for a neo-noir kind of investigation and paints the dystopian streets of Los Angeles in a decadent, almost gothic tone that reminds of his rainy London.Thematically, the plot raises questions about what it means to be human in a time where there is no perceivable difference between man and machine, to the point that even the nature of memories is to be questioned. These are pretty common reflections in sci-fi literature, and I always thought that "Blade Runner" limited itself to giving some cues without digging too deep into the mind of its characters for the sake of the few moments of action (the critics basically did the rest writing pages and pages of overanalyzing). Rick Deckard's motivation for what he does is never fully explored, and so is his rather forced relationship with Rachael. He walks around and defeats one replicant after another like in an arcade fighting game. The film makes a point to show how the androids are more united and human than the morally decayed men of 2019, but little screen time is devoted to exploring their nature.An impressive film for its time and solid cyberpunk neo-noir, but definitely not what I would call an all-time masterpiece.
reviews.heading: Still looks amazing

reviews.content: Whilst hyped up during the watch of this movie I was amazed by the scenery and cinematography - and EVEN MORE when I remembered this was made back in 1984.The script written for this movie was ridiculously impressive. The beginning of each scene gave the viewer so many questions they wanted to get answered, gripping the audience in an intense desire. I felt so myself and couldn't get more satisfied with the potrayal of them. The characters could seem flat and overall boring - but it is the words they say that give so much meaning to the film that is truly important, and the Director knew this.Oh and the score fit in sooo smoothly, I felt I the original style was becoming even more original with this.All the compliments aside however, the original filmstyle did not cling as emotionally wishful to me as I wanted. In itself it seems near perfection, but I miss something that truly makes me attached to the film. Could it be the characters and relating to them? Possibly, but I'll leave that question for the next rewatch.
reviews.heading: A Unique Style

reviews.content: No matter what the trouble at the movie making , when the movie is finished and make an impact it's all that matters. Blade Runner made a huge impact and still today a beloved cult classic.
reviews.heading: Best classic of all time

reviews.content: Harrison Ford plays a Blade Runner hired to 'retire' a number of highly dangerous bioengineered replicants in a dystopian future.One of the most influential of science fiction films, it was hard to believe it was not a success when first released. It has been re-edited several times by director Ridley Scott to create different versions - with the Final Cut, the now definitive version. The cast are universally excellent with Ford spot on as the brutal, disenchanted 'killer' falling in love with one of the replicants, played by Sean Young and Rutger Hauer pretty well steals the show as the frightening replicant leader who delivers the now famous speech, which he apparently wrote, near the end of the film. What takes this beyond just a sharp storyline is the imagination used in creating this futuristic environment - all dark, neon lights and acid rain and all utterly convincing. Coupling all this with Vangelis' sublime score and you have a neigh on perfect sci fi movie.
reviews.heading: Blade Runner

reviews.content: "Blade Runner" is a terrible film, so bad that I stopped halfway through as it was giving me a headache. The constant strobing effect of the lighting really bothered me as I have some neurological issues. Anyone else susceptible to such things should avoid this film. Beyond that, there was nothing to keep me involved: dim scenery, few locations, weak script, boring, slow, etc. Skip this one, it is not worth the time -- there are so many better science-fiction films out there. Not sure why this one gets high ratings. 1/10.
reviews.heading: Terrible - epileptics avoid

reviews.content: The sets, the atmosphere, music, story, acting, costumes, and special fx give this film a feel unlike any other and is still excites me to this day.They just don't make them like this anymore.
reviews.heading: One of the best sci-fi films that stands the test of time

reviews.content: Based on the book in my headline title this film is a visual treat with a stunning soundtrack. A Science Fiction Noir most commonly known now as "Cyberpunk" and doesnt follow the usual Sci-Fi tropes and is better for it. Blade Runner describes a future in which through genetics artificial humans are manufactured and called replicants. Made by Tyrell Corporation the replicants not only resembles humans but they are far superior physically. The replicants were declared illegal on planet Earth after a bloody mutiny occurred Mars where they worked as slaves. A special police force known as the Blade Runners is in charge of identifying, tracking and killing the fugitive replicants found on Earth. With a group of replicants loose in Los Angeles, Rick Deckard (Harrison Ford) who is the best agent that has existed in regard to the recovery and removal of the replicas, is removed from his semi-retirement to eradicate them from the city. The cast is great and no matter which version you choose to watch you cant help but fall in love with this film.
reviews.heading: DO ANDROIDS DREAM OF ELECTRIC SHEEP?

reviews.content: My gosh, aftert all these years, still i watch this piece of gold, like the first time i did(when i was 7 or 8 years old) and still i like it as i did before! Hell no i lov it, and its the only movie of 'harrison ford' that he did not ruind!
reviews.heading: the only good movie, of Harrison Ford!

reviews.content: First of all, I REALLY want to like this movie since I love sci-fi movies. I first saw it in december last year and the movie left me very disappointed. I just rewatched it, hoping that I missed something the first time I watched it, but it didnt get any better on rewatch. I'll start with a positive note ; Everything in this film looks absolutely fantastic. For design and production it gets a 10/10. But asside from that, the movie gives me pretty much nothing else to enjoy. The plot was uninteresting and the pacing was too slow. Besides Rutger Hauers character, all the other characters in this movie were among the most boring and monotone I have ever seen, which makes me not care about any of them. All that happened in the movie was basically just Harrison Ford and Rutger Hauer going from place to place to interrogate people and kill them. I still rate it 6/10 because the design kept me sort of entertained and the final battle was ok I guess. It may sound very controversial but Blade Runner 2049 is a much better movie.
reviews.heading: All style, no plot

reviews.content: Massive milestone in science fiction but watch the directors cut.
reviews.heading: One of the best movies of all tome

reviews.content: Why is the high rating for this movie ? Seriously ! Even a monkey has a great taste to rate. I've already wasted 2 hours of my precious life.
reviews.heading: I've wasted 2 hours of my life.

reviews.content:
After watching the Blade Runner, he dreamed about a unicorn, it reminds me I dreamed it as well, once.No, it's not one, it's they.I remembered at that time I could only feel pure joy, as if I was holding a telescope,
Like childhood play toy,
What does it mean, that was my most beautiful time out of reality, it's in dream.It says: The unicorn symbolism is linked to purity, freedom, gentleness, virginity, innocence, divinity, and magic. Christians believe that the unicorn symbol is that of Christ and Mother Mary themselves. Seeing unicorns in dreams is inevitably a sign of good luck, happiness, and a positive omen.Aren't we like Deckard, but the only difference is : he knew he live in a world where there is the replicants and the human, so he could be one of the two , but we don't have any doubt absolutely with the world we live in, as a fan of Sci-fi movies, after watching them ( the blade runner, Matrix) , you will start to doubt yourself, if memory and feeling could implant in our brain, I mean , if it just some thing like putting a button inside you then triggering you having a certain reaction, that was a kind of I don't know, it's a very weird feeling, gives you a shiver.
reviews.heading: He was dreamed of a unicorn

reviews.content: Well, this is my first movie review, and I'm doing it out of outrage. Recently I became interested in cinema and, as a way to broaden my "horizons", I tried to watch some "cult" movies, and all of that ended up watching "Blade Runner". I confess that I was very disappointed with the movie, I imagined an amazing movie, which could even be one of my favorite movies, but it wasn't what I got. In fact, the movie's script is TERRIBLE, the only thing that saves it from 4/10 is its photography and direction. The movie is very slow, I was even sleepy, and with some very questionable scenes, like the first kiss between Deckard and Rachel. Also, people have always talked about how impactful the final fight scene is, but I didn't think that scene was as amazing as they say. Anyway, I'm going to watch "Blade Runner 2049", which is the continuation of this universe, I hope I don't regret it either.
reviews.heading: Good direction, but the screenplay is bad.

reviews.content: Probably the ideal candidate for B lik ade Runner would be someone who's a fan of sci-fi futuristic movies and film-noir police mysteries as it is a blend of the two genres.It takes place in the not too distant future of 2019(at this point, the past) and follows a special sort of cop who's job is to kill find and kill rogue robots-which is the subject of the investigation he's assigned. What exactly he's supposed to do, or more specifically, what he does remains very unclear. No matter how attentively you might watch this film I doubt you'll be able to fully comprehend the plot. Which makes it that much harder to stay with, especially when it already has such a subdued pace. For all its robots, flying cars and advanced technology it actually isn't the high speed, action packed movie you might suspect. I think its perfectly alright or better that it isn't, but the picture swings too far to the other side and goes into the realm of dull.I might understand how some viewers might like aspects such as the film's art direction, score or even Harrison Ford. But the cult-like following of Blade Runner take it beyond that type of appreciation and place the film on a height much higher than it deserves.
reviews.heading: Doesn't Live Up To The Hype At All

reviews.content: Blade Runner is a film that is by Ridley Scott ( Alien), that came out in 1982. This movie has stunning visuals, and a great story line. Their are about 4 different versions of the movie. The version I like the best is the one, Deckard ( Harrison Ford), and his mini-narrative. His thoughts, and characters background. He doesn't talk throughout the movie, but his narrative explains it more.This is the director's Cut, which is really good. I didn't see this movie until I was in my 20's. I was blown away by the opening scene. The story is about Synthetic Humans that were created to work on off-word colonies. They were designed with a 4 year life span. This was a fail safe measure, encase they decided to turn on their creator. They are also referred as Replicates or Skin-Jobs, and are very unpredictable. When 4 Replicates escape from an off -world colonies an alert goes out to the enforcers or BLADE RUNNERS. They are looking for two males and two females. The leader is Roy Batty ( Late Rudgar Hauer), Leon ( Brion James ), Pris ( Daryl Hannah), and Zhora ( Joanna Cassidy). They are headed back to Earth to seek a longer life span. They want to find Tyrell ( James Turkel), and are willing to do anything or stop anybody from getting in their way. Leon is the most dangerous, when he was interviewed, he almost kills is interviewer ( Mark Arnold).Deckard is a burnt out cop/Blade Runner who is the best. He is called back to track down the 4 and kill them. He works alongside Gaff ( Edward James Olmos). When Deckard is called by The Tyrell Cor. To interview Tyrell's assistant Racheal. He is shocked because she is young and gorgeous. It takes him longer, but Deckard discovers she is a replicaint. Tyrell says she is the best work he has created, which took Deckard longer to find out. She believe she is human, but Deckard tells her it's all fake memories. They begin a relationship and knows he has to protect her from other Blade Runners, especially his boss who knows what she is. Deckard begins to eliminate the replicants, but two remain Pris and Batty. They are very dangerous and find Sebastian. He also works with Tyrell, and is brilliant. Sebastian doesn't realize he is being played, they just friend him til they can get to Tyrell. When Batty meets Tyrell, he kills him and Sebastian. The reason he would not give into his demands of a longer lifespan.Deckard is called along with Gaff to investigate. He realizes he must eliminate the last 2. In order to keep Rachael safe he keeps her at his place until he returns. His plan is to leave with her after the job is done. He finds Batty and Pris, Pris almost kills him, but he is able to escape then she blows a socket. So Roy is the last, but he doesn't give up. It is a back and fourth game with the two. Batty knows his time is about up, and when a mishap happens he save Deckard from certain death. The two look at each other with Batty releasing a Dove, then he dies.When Deckard returns he realizes Gaff has been in is apartment, because he leaves clues( origami). When he fears the worst, he runs over to check on Rachael, she is still alive. The two leave fearing what would happen if he stayed. This is a great film which I have always wondered if Deckard was a Repliciant or not. It does make U wonder, but this movie is a must see.
reviews.heading: A Dangerous And Futuristic Look At A Dystopian Los Angeles, 2019.

reviews.content: I cant believe this flick was released in 1982 .i can praise this movie all i want but it wouldnt do justice .you have to see it yourself. The set and cinematography is way ahead of its time.you will feel like living in those conditions with those characters. Good performances from everyone specialy Mr Rutger did great job.
reviews.heading: Surreal and breathtaking experience

reviews.content: Blade Runner is a revolutionary Science Fiction film with visuals that still hold up decades after its release. A thought-provoking film, Blade Runner is larger on ideas than action as the movie is a very slow and bleak ride. Blade Runner is not a film I enjoyed watching much but was one I was still thinking about after viewing and appreciate more for its reputation than my actual viewing experience. Reading other's glowing reviews makes me want to give this a higher rating, but from an entertainment standpoint I found this to be an average movie.
reviews.heading: Sci-fi Classic That May Bore You

reviews.content: Just saw the final cut (2007) and liked it better. No soliloqui from Rick Deckard. A cleaner and more logical storyline. Some added bits. It's strange to be happening in 2019 though, could have pushed the date further 100 years. Cigarettes look past millenium now. The constant rain is funny since LA is always sunny.
reviews.heading: New cut is better

reviews.content: Watched all the versions over the years, the Final Cut being the best (which doesn't have the narration of the original theatrical release).I love the minimalist spareness of this dystopian script. The original score is something to behold also. It is a film that is admired from filmmakers to architects alike.The sequel was not really required, but forgivable as a means of nostalgia.
reviews.heading: Beautifully Melancholic Dystopia.

reviews.content: Everything in this movie is perfect. There is no mistakes its just perfect! I have watch movie 1000 times, and i will watch it 10 000 times. PERFECT!
reviews.heading: My favorite movie!

reviews.content: The concept of robots turning against their creators is crafted so well in this masterpiece of SciFi. The visual imagery is jaw dropping for its time. The detail and effort that went into every scene blows the mind.This film was brilliant in so many ways. One for the generations.
reviews.heading: A steampunk dystopian nightmare

reviews.content: Blade Runner kicked off one of the best (the all-time best to me personally) sci-fi films and futuristic stories/world ever. The film is a true masterpiece that presented its world very differently and in a unique way that no one can create especially during the time which the film was released (the 80s).Ridley Scott directed the film perfectly. The characters were so unique and interesting especially that the film left us with so many unanswered questions about them and other things so it made the fans want to know more about the characters and the story itself. The dialogues/monologues were so interesting and sometimes deep with their meanings, and yes I'm talking about the famous, incredible, and deep monologue "Tears in Rain" or the "C-Beams Speech" that although it was only 42 words, people still talk about how beautiful it is until this day and they will continue talking about it of course. Rutger Hauer (Plays Roy Batty) made this monologue/scene even better with his facial expressions and voice tone. It was also him who changed some of the words of this monologue from the original script a day before the shooting of this scene so the result would be the one we all watched in the film.The perfect music score of Vangelis was so unique and different and did fit that futuristic world of Blade Runner perfectly. It also did fit every scene whether it was a love/romantic scene, or a scene where the Blade Runner is chasing someone or being chased by someone, or even an emotional/deep scene like the "Tears in Rain" monologue that had a piece of perfect music playing in the background that was called "Tears in rain" too.Really loved Harrison Ford's performance as Rick Dickered. He played the role of the Blade Runner perfectly. Sean Young as Racheal was able to convince me that she is a "Replicant". In my opinion, anyone who played the role of a "Replicant" in the film, did it more than well and they all convinced me.Jordan Cronenweth's cinematography was great and it was able to capture the futuristic world in a way that'll blow your mind especially when it comes to showing buildings that had these futuristic/beautiful billboards, or even the flying cars. This brings me to the production design that worked so well alongside the cinematography to capture this beautiful big world.Loved how the film left us with so many unanswered questions (that even most of them aren't answered in the sequel "Blade Runner 2049"). Because this makes the film more debatable and we get to hear the different theories and opinions.Great film that introduced us to a beautiful, big, complex, and futuristic world. It had a great cast & crew that delivered a film that lives for years.My rating is 9.5/10."Time to die"
reviews.heading: "All those moments will be lost in time, like tears in rain."

reviews.content: People just seem to get kicks out of trashing things with cult followings, get a life! Groundbreaking design and cinematography that still holds up. Acting and script is hammy and ridiculous in places, but it was 1982! Just like Star Wars, its the world Ridley Scott created that is the best thing about it, so many possibilities and spawned an entire sub genre of Sci fi. Obviously not 1 star trash, and objectively not 10 star perfection along the lines of the Godfather.I like it.And by the way. Deckard was a replicant. I have no idea why they removed that entire story undercurrent from the sequel, other than to give Harrison another pay day. The origami unicorn was the big reveal.
reviews.heading: Why are trolls out downgrading this with one star reviews?

reviews.content: Outdated and definitely feels aged. There are plenty of scenes that just outright feel awkward and strange for today. I also found myself laughing at a few moments that I'm guessing were meant to be serious. It's probably because much of the acting doesn't feel very believable.But even apart from this, the film manages to still maintain your attention.The visual effects, cinematography and film score are by far the best part of this experience. Vangelis' work is mesmerizing and really immerses you into this cyberpunk world. Without it, the film would be half as good.Entertaining enough and enjoyable.
reviews.heading: Outdated. but still entertaining.

reviews.content: Don't understand why this film has such a high rating. I mean it's ok but nothing special. I get that it would have looked great at a cinema in the 1980s but the plot and characterisation are pretty weak.
reviews.heading: Overrated

reviews.content: I understand it was something big in the 80s but it's not timeless and it's not stunning and it's not deep. Idk what people see in it, everything is bad, cinematography is bad (maybe good for the 80s but bad to me). There's no storyline whatsoever, everyone have no motive and make worst decisions ever. Everyone is very unlikeable and shallow it was a torture watching all of it. And it's Just always raining and dark and the sounds don't go quiet well, neither is the lightening. I literally got a migraine watching this.I heard Blade runner 2049 is supposedly worse so I ain't watching it. I don't need more shallow characters and bad sounds and bad lightening to give me another migraine.
reviews.heading: Sucks and not even nearly as good as they yay

reviews.content: I often hear similar stories of people's first experiences watching Blade Runner, finding the film dull but coming to appreciate it years later - my story has the same trajectory. I first tried to watch Blade Runner (of what I believe was The Final Cut) on TV in Christmas 2009, only to stop watching after half an hour due to boredom. Over the years, however, I would be compelled to return to Blade Runner several times and get more out of it with each viewing. The tech-noir world of Blade Runner is one to get lost in with its use of neon and many billboards of geishas, albeit a more depressing, dystopian one than say that of Star Wars; one in which the city of Los Angeles appears to be stuck in a state of perpetual darkness and it very frequently rains. Now when watching Blade Runner, I'm watching a movie set in the past date of November, 2019. Once again, like Star Wars, the technology present is highly contradictory, this is a world in which flying cars exist and photographs have unimaginably high pixel counts, yet they still use CRT televisions and mobile phones don't appear to exist. It contradictions like these which we can observe in the real world just adds to the unique and fantasy aspect of the Blade Runner universe.The visual style of Blade Runner has since become a massive cliché - often imitated but never equaled. It feels like every shot or background prop has a story to tell such as those many photographs in Rick Deckard's apartment. The man-cave interior of Deckard's apartment is perfectly suited to his loner personality, a classic world-weary noir protagonist. The film's blurring of the lines between what is human and what is machine results in me always having to remind myself that these replicants of whose plight I've drawn emotional investment towards, are not humans at the end of the day. Why should I feel sorry for the vulnerable replicant Rachael with her smudged eye makeup created from her tears? Blade Runner provokes many a thought of what it means to be human. I suspect the appearance of Rachael must have come about from a desire to create an ideal woman since nobody else in Blade Runner casually dresses like a 1940's femme fatale (I haven't heard of anyone else note Rachael has a strong resemblance to Rosalind Russell in My Sister Eileen from 1942). Likewise, I don't want to know if Deckard is a replicant or not, I prefer the ambiguity and the mystery along with the many unanswered questions of this universe.The love scene between Deckard and Rachael is one of the greatest in cinema history. The sexual tension builds up as a shirtless Deckard wipes away the blood of his face and Rachael lets her hair loose. Subsequently, the manner in which Deckard prevents Rachael from leaving the apartment as he shuts the door with his fist and then proceeds to kiss her along with the saxophone solo from the love them being as close to cheesy as it can get without it being so, brings the swoon factor up to 11. My shallow desires just wish the extended, deleted version of the scene was left in any of the version of the film (in the 80's Sean Young got to have a sex scene with both Harrison Ford and Kevin Costner).The effects of globalization as seen in Blade Runner present L. A. (or at the very least one portion of the city) having Japanese inhabitants as the majority population. If the filmmakers were intending to make accurate predictions of the future, the world of Blade Runner would be more likely dominated by Chinese influence. What Blade Runner does reflect accurately about our modern world is the increasingly oppressive corporate culture and the surveillance of everyday life. There are no evident signs of government in Blade Runner yet corporations rule the roast as the Mayan pyramid-shaped headquarters of the Tyrell Corporation dominates the skyline. Like Cyberdyne Systems in The Terminator and Omni Consumer Products in Robocop, 1980's pulp sci-fi tried to warn us of the dangers of unbridled corporate power. Such power is seen turning in on itself as the film's corporate overlord, the slimy, dubious Eldon Tyrell with his magnificent glasses succumbs to a gruesome death in the only moment of the film in which I want to avert my eyes from the screen in a classic case of the Frankenstein monster turning on its creator. It's little often pointed out that Tyrell's death is very similar to the murder of Mr. Gaines in The Manchurian Candidate (1962). In both films, the murders take place at night in the victim's bedroom as they are lying in bed reading. Both characters are wearing a robe while having a chessboard, statues of animals and candles next to their beds.Lucas and Spielberg gave special editions a bad name, but Ridley Scott's Final Cut of Blade Runner actually shows they have a place (providing the option of viewing the original still exists). There are no pointless CGI additions and it fixes the niggling technical flaws of the original such as the shot of Roy Batty's dove flying towards the sky. While I appreciate the Final Cut, there is a charm to those imperfections of the original, showing that even the masters can make mistakes. I will also defend the voice-over narration present in the theatrical version. It's not up to the poetic quality of Fred MacMurray in Double Indemnity and is hokey but I find it endearingly so and does make the plot easier to follow and gives the film a bit more character (plus we get to hear Harrison Ford drop the "N" word).Blade Runner is by no means a nihilistic film, rather it is one that shows beauty in despair (the original ending shows that green pastures apparently still exist in this world of ecological ruin). This display of goodness, truth and beauty culminates in Roy Batty's final 42 word Tears In The Rain monologue, as the obviously Christ-like figure conjures magnificent images of Attack ships on fire off the shoulder of Orion and C-beams glittering in the dark near the Tannhäuser Gate to the magnificent score by Vangelis. The Blade Runner soundtrack is one of the few film scores in which I can listen to the entire thing (even John Williams Ladd Company jingle is awe-inspiring). It is the perfect accompaniment to walking down any urban landscapes at night (I can recall multiple mornings when I would listen to Tears In The Rain as the sun would rise back when I worked night shifts) as oneself reflects over its romantic nature and harkens for nostalgia, often and like the replicants in the movie, for memories we don't even have.
reviews.heading: I've Seen The Future And It Will Be

reviews.content: It really doesn't get any better than "Blade Runner". So much has been said about it what could I even add? In terms of Science Fiction this one stands alone at the very top. In all its many "cuts" and alternate versions the one thing that remains constant is this films sheer brilliance.
reviews.heading: The Greatest

reviews.content: Ridley Scott is one of the most grandiose, self-serving directors I've ever read about. I hate to support someone who thinks there's the pinnacle of cinema, but Blade Runner is a terrific film. The first time I watched it I was thoroughly unimpressed. It's slow pacing and dull atmosphere made me question why it was such a sci-fi classic. Multiple rewatches, though, have led me to understand that the world building is absolutely fantastic: a fully living, breathing world. The film asks what it means to be human and borrows some important themes from the original source material from Philip K. Dick. Harrison Ford plays a low energy blade runner but his interactions with the replicants are critical and human. I give Blade Runner a 9/10.
reviews.heading: Too bad she won't live!

reviews.content: An existencial and nostalgic story. The way this movie sent the audience its true message is mind-blowing. It was so ahead of its time, it's hard to believe it came out in 1982. It's about the underlying causes of what makes someone human and not the questioning of wether someone is a Replicant or not. Asking that is just missing the point. Isn't just humanity the result of a conscious and rational mind? Isn't our humanity defined by our memories, our senses and feelings, our incredibly short lives compared to the ever expanding universe? Aren't we all just biological machines? So what does that make Replicants? Aren't they just the same machines but with a shorter lifespan? Living in fear, just wanting to be free - that being the 'itch they can never scratch'. No one is the villain in this movie, and I find that confusing yet beautiful. Morality is, therefore, represented by a social construct.The aesthetics and acting of the film are immaculate. The soundtrack does the 'man's job' and the final monologue was what made me love this movie the most. It will always be relevant, no matter what.
reviews.heading: Existencialism and modern philosophy

reviews.content: Classy Science fi about a futuristic Detective Philip Marlowe-style attempting to find and kill the world's remaining rebel androids and synthetically produced humans in 2917 Los Ángeles. As he takes down one by one , but then things go wrong . These replicants with only days left to life , search badly for some way to extend their prescribed lifetimes .Atmospheric , moody and thought-provoking Sci-Fi based on "Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep" by Philip K Dick. This is an impressive , dark and visually breathtaking tale that will appeal very much to cinema lovers . Fabulous sets and production design from an architect's dream. As state-of-art special effects and wonderful settings of this 21st century detective yarn are overwhelming , even if the storyline takes some following , at times . Main and support cast are frankly awesome . Harrison Ford gives a terrific acting as a world-weary detective who tracks down a handful of deadly renegades . He is well accompanied by a very good cast , such as : Sean Young , Edward James Olmos , Joe Turkel , Joanna Cassidy , William Sanderson , Daryl Hanna , M Emmet Walsh , Brian James and special mention for Rutger Hauer , including his unforgettable final scenes.It contains an exciting and rousing musical score by Vangelis , marvellously composed by synthesizer. As well as brilliant and lush cinematography by Jordan Cronenwerth . The motion picture was stunningly directed by Ridley Scott , developind the moving action amid attractive visuals that even surpass those in this great filmmaker 's former movie Alien . It was followed by a late and nice sequel in 2017 Blade Runner 2049 by Denis Villeneuve with Ryan Gosling , Dave Bautista , Ana de Armas , Janed Leto , Robin Wright , and Edward James Olmos and of course Harrison Ford .
reviews.heading: A genuine and classic Science Fiction movie with thrills , emotion , intrigue and beautifully photographed

reviews.content: I just had to say if it wasn't for the score this movie would be a lot less watchable
reviews.heading: The score is one thing that won me over

reviews.content: This was definitely ahead of time. Endeavouring to do something with the concepts of immortality, death, morbidity and consumerism, is definitely a good take on how Communism can be deadly in the modern context. The subjects like Marxist perspective on humans' lifespan and their productivity is very relatable in today's era when many nations have begun to try a hand at expansion of robots and their capability to protect human's lifespan. But the major issue is what if the manufacturers of robots do not envisage the actual lifespan of robots? Are humans capable of making immortal robots? If no, what are the chances that the future of robots will be possible even when humans will perish?More thematic discussion in next review.
reviews.heading: Exploration of finding immortality in mortals

reviews.content: The cinematography, set design, and overall mode are excellent. The unnerving feel this movie elicits is perfect for what you'd want from a neo-noir film!I thought acts one and two were great! But the finally, act three, just dropped the ball for me. The final act focuses far too much on an action that really does. It add to what the movie was trying to accomplish. Furthermore, the movie feels like it is still missing an overarching point that is never resolved.I would actually say Bladerunner 2049 is better, if only because it feels like it resolves itself.
reviews.heading: It Looks Great!! ....

reviews.content: When it comes to highly beloved science-fiction films that left a huge cultural impact, one that comes to mind is Blade Runner, loosely based on Philip K. Dick's Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep. Despite failing to generate much of an audience on its original release due to misguided marketing and a terribly botched theatrical cut, the film slowly but surely garnished a massive following to the point of being hailed as one of the greatest sci-fi movies ever made, as well as best films ever made, partially thanks to its reformed final cuts. That being said, while I admire the film's legacy, let's just say I respect it more than I enjoy it.Set in a dystopian future Los Angeles around 2019, where synthetic humans called replicants have been bio-engineered by the Tyrell Corporation to work in space, a group of fugitive advanced replicants led by Roy Batty escape back to Earth. So it's all up to a jaded cop Rick Deckard to hunt them down while dealing with an emotional replicant named Rachel who wishes to be human. Right off the bat, what makes the movie iconic is the world building, as the entire setting of this futuristic Los Angeles is just oozing with gritty atmosphere and a frightening aroma of criminal activity going around. In a way, the film mixes neo-noir with sci-fi in a very unique setting that it allows the environments to speak for themselves.
