Also, the aforementioned replicants are quite fascinating in concept, especially with how determined they are to get back at the Tyrell corporation for their poor treatment of them, and the likes of Rutger Hauer, Daryl Hannah, Brion James and Joanna Cassidy bring each character to life in their own special ways, even if Hauer steals the show with Roy Batty's subtly haunting demeanor.Speaking of performances, Harrison Ford really sells the mentally exhausted Deckard to the point where we as the viewers can identify with him the most. Knowing all the complicated details that go behind the caper and the occasional action packed sequences that show up, it allows for Deckard to thoroughly use his brains as opposed to his brawn, like a real detective. However, outside of Deckard and the replicants, the remaining cast ranges from general plot conveniences to underdeveloped potential, as the movie would rather focus on the specific mission than make them really stand out. The only true stand out is J.F. Sebastian, the genetic designer who Pris and Roy manipulate to get back at Tyrell. In addition to his fondness for crafting exquisitely elaborate toys, he ends up having a similar predicted fate as the replicants, making him just as sympathetic as them. It's characters like that which make the story more engaging than it might have been beforehand thanks to the added bits of substance you don't often get in the sci-fi genre.With that said though, what does keep me from deeming Blade Runner great is how slowly paced it is. I'm all for a neo-noir crime thriller to take its time in solving the case, but the down to earth maturity makes the film feel more hollow than if it was more action packed. Also, despite being interesting in theory, Rachel isn't really given enough screen time to be as memorable as she could have been, and whenever she does show up, it usually just has to do with her coming to an emotional resonance around Deckard (not helped by an unsettling and unnecessary implied romance). Not to mention, by the time the movie gets to the third act in resolving the crime case, it just ends off in a standard suspenseful shoot 'em up, not uncommon in other crime flicks. Finally, because there are so many cuts of the movie, you may end up with a different view depending on which one you watch. Granted, it was nice to view the final cut, but when the theatrical cut has a happy ending that is tonally disconnected from the film's intended tone, that will just leave more to be desired than satisfied.So all in all, while Blade Runner might not be a personal favorite, even I can't deny the amazing impact it left on cinema. Had it not been for its underground status that led it to being hailed as a classic, we wouldn't have other innovative sci-fi media like Battlestar Galactica, Akira, Ghost in the Shell, Deus Ex, etc. Seeing as how the film eventually spawned its own sequel made more than 30 years after its original release, its legacy lives on for new generations to come. Faithful to Dick's work or not, all of the films moments in history will never be lost to time, like tears in rain.
reviews.heading: More Impactful than Memorable

reviews.content: The story is a little bit hard to follow, but all the other things this movie offers make up for it. The world they created for this movie, is one of the most immersive worlds I've seen in a film. You can easily imagine the daily life of anyone in that city. Don't even get me started on the special effects. This movie is almost 40 YEARS old! I only wish I saw it back then, so I would be even more blown away.
reviews.heading: Immersive

reviews.content: Gaff is the most powerful, enigmatic character ever...
reviews.heading: I NEVER give a 10 rating, but Blade Runner deserves it...

reviews.content: The completely out-of-the-box story, the cast and its nighttime magic that included unique dialogues and also the soundtrack, makes this is movie the best ever made !
reviews.heading: Best....

reviews.content: "How could this be possibly made in 1982?" A question I asked myself after a few minutes of the movie. The visuals were stunning and it really felt like a cyberpunk world. I mean I watched many movies and played many video games that are under the genre of cyberpunk, but Blade Runner? That was on a far superior level, exceptional. The marvelous experimental soundtrack score did really fit each single scene. I can easily confirm that this was by far the most atmospheric experience I've ever had. I didn't even get started with the storyline and the structure. It was extraordinarily presented in a simple approach that was as well deeply sophisticated. It easily managed to grab your attention from the very first minute of the movie, and that last scene? Outstanding, superior, genius, perfect.
reviews.heading: A perfectly-adapted dystopian cyberpunk masterpiece.

reviews.content: Rick Deckard is given an assignment to 'retire' several biologically engineered fugitives.I love Blade Runner for it's visual beauty, themes and how it mixes two of my favourite movie genres: noir and sci-fi.The plot follows Deckard as he hunts replicants, falls in love and questions his own humanity. It moves deliberately slow, allowing you to take in all the sights and sounds of 2019 Los Angeles (as imagined in 1982), whilst pondering some of the themes it presents.If you want to know more about the philosophical themes in significant depth, I suggest you google 'Blade Runner Themes and Motifs'. A simple Welshman like myself would for the purpose of a review rather scratch the surface and say that the imagery and dialogue associated with what defines a sentient being and what makes us human is compellingly portrayed. The device used to explore these themes is the genetically engineered humanoid life-form, the godlike status of its creator and the morally compromised nature of the ordinary human. Additionally the number of references to the eyes and linking of what we see and remember versus what is fake and reality, is cleverly mixed into the story.The character of Roy Batty has been interpreted as both a religious and philosophical allegory, but these types of theories can be argued until the sheep come home. He is for me the most intriguing character in the movie and his final scene is one of the most memorable of all time. Along with Deckard, it made me actually wonder if there is any real difference between humans and replicants. He is portrayed wonderfully by Rutger Hauer who both looks and acts the part.Deckard is impressively played by Harrison Ford, who is perfect for movies with such an emphasis on visuals. Ninety percent of Ford's power as an actor comes from his striking visual presence and soulful facial expressions. His scenes with Sean Young young are as emotionally touching as the action scenes are brutal.One of Blade Runner's most memorable aspects is its depiction of 2019 Los Angeles, with its permanently dark rainy skies, overcrowding, neon lights, high concept technology, urban decay and environmental devastation. Take away the flying cars and off-world colonies and it's not far off an accurate prediction.I could write for hours about the cinematography, artistic designs and special effects, but there's nothing I can say that would do it justice. You should watch every incredibly atmospheric frame of Blade Runner and absorb what Ridley Scott is showing you.The much argued question of whether Deckard is a replicant or a human is interesting. There is evidence on both sides of the argument and you must watch the movie to decide. I ask myself, does it really matter? Personally, I think in the grand scheme of the movie it matters as much as whether Welshmen dream of inflatable sheep. If I had to decide though, I'd say that he is a replicant.
reviews.heading: Do Welshmen dream of inflatable sheep?

reviews.content: The aesthetics are mindblowing, even in 2021, but the plot is dull, weak and predictable.I had to skip over several scenes that were unnecessarily violent and some other things were absolutely unconvincing - such as always finding the one person you're looking for in the most overcrowded city of all times, or the love story that you can see coming from miles away. As much as I enjoy slow-paced and ambient films, Blade Runner's slowness is due to its ridiculous lack of plot development. The story is one big void.Good visuals sadly aren't a seal of a quality story.
reviews.heading: A boring visual gem

reviews.content:
More of a film than a movie. every scene is captivating. slow but smooth, cohesive, intense, and fascinating. it flows and jaunts and then it's over.would watch again
will watch again
reviews.heading: more of an experience than a movie

reviews.content: One of the greatest films ever. Ridley Scott's best film. So ahead of it's time and still relevant today. Visually amazing. A must watch for movie bluffs.
reviews.heading: Scifi Noir Masterpiece

reviews.content: I understand it paved the way for all of the ideals we have now about this futuristic genre. it looks really nice. the soundtrack rolling on the end credits was the most exciting part of the movie. Very slow movie, weak plot, it doesn't age well in my opinion.
reviews.heading: a necessary introduction to cyberpunk genre

reviews.content: I first saw this movie about 20 years ago on DVD and although I didn't remember much except for the beginning I always thought of it as a good movie.Well 20 years later and close to 40 since it's release and this movie just couldn't hold my interest. There's practically no plot, I guess were supposed to know everything already because it's a classic and has like 4 different versions. Harrison Fords acting is really not very good and many of the characters speak strangely and don't make sense.When you compare it to all the other terrible movies at the time, like Gremlins, this movie would seem very good but today it's just another puzzling relic that fanboys and nostalgia have warped into a classic.
reviews.heading: Is it just dated, or is it the Final Cut version?

reviews.content: I have mixed feelings on this movie. For one, I think the special effects and world building are amazing along with the performances (especially Rutger Hauer), but I think that there are some problems with the story. Like, for example, Harrison Ford is kinda just thrusted into the story. He doesn't really have a motivation to be in the story. One scene with him and Brion James goes on for a little too long. The romance between Ford and Sean Young is pretty bad. I'd still recommend it, though and I look forward to the sequel, Blade Runner 2049.P.s.: I watched Blade Runner 2049 and it is epic! I definitely recommend Blade Runner 2049!
reviews.heading: Flawed, but creative

reviews.content: Pauline Kael was dead wrong when she argued you could totally get a movie on the first viewing. BLADE RUNNER is one such movie which only deepens with every viewing. I've come to find that the way I approach the movie has changed so much from when I first saw it years ago-- elements I originally viewed as flaws, such as Deckard being far less sympathetic and engaging than his replicant quarry, are actually strengths. That Deckard is more machine-like and cold than his prey is precisely part of the point the film is making about humanity in the modern world, not unlike HAL 9000 being far more human than the flesh and blood human beings in 2001: A SPACE ODYSSEY.Beyond that, BLADE RUNNER is a triumph of worldbuilding and atmosphere. Both the gloomy, ethereal Vangellis score and the smoky, noir visuals combine to create the most beautiful nightmarescape ever put on-screen. There's something hypnotic about BLADE RUNNER, though this very quality pretty much demands that you need to be in the proper mood to watch it.
reviews.heading: A beautiful nightmare

reviews.content: This movie is not just a classic, it's good. I saw this when it came out, and the various different versions over years, including a re-screening of rare copy of the original cinematic release at the Boston Sci-fi movie marathon maybe about 10 years ago. From Harrison Ford to Rutger Hauer to Sean Young to Daryl Hannah, this is solid from beginning to end no matter what version you're watching. The atmosphere is great, the story top-notch, the casting and acting completely appropriate. Still worth re-watching, even after almost 40 years... ugh, I'm getting old!
reviews.heading: Must see

reviews.content:
I remember the first time a saw Blade Runner - a thoroughly stunning experience overall - although the narration was distracting and the end just didn't match the overall dark tone of the Film. You can imagine then how I felt when it became apparent that Director Ridley Scott wanted to remove both! Whether you see the 'Director's Cut' or the recent 'Final Cut', Blade Runner is simply a dystopian visual masterpiece about where mankind is heading and the consequences of creating ever more complex AI. Loosely based on the Phil Dick novel 'Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep' Scott's vision is a dark, resonant, neon-lit cityscape, where giant Corporate adverts play in the rainy gloom. Rick Deckard is a 'Blade Runner' - an investigator who hunts down any 'replicants' (artificially created human-forms) who have rebelled against their programming. The new Nexus 6 are a problem - if they can imitate human behaviour well enough - they may be able to fool the Test that differentiates Humans from Replicants and several of the new Nexus 6 have arrived back on earth for reasons that are not immediately apparent.
The entire Film poses a fundamental question - when do artificially created entities become sentient? What rights do they have, if any? Do they 'become' Human or merely imitate our feelings? There are no easy answers here.
This is NOT Science Fiction in the Terminator-type vein - explosions, battle scenes etc. This is REAL Science Fiction, where it builds a credible world to ask difficult Questions - and what a world it is. We can forget now how extraordinary Blade Runner looked in 1982 when it was first released and maybe the reason it looks slightly more familiar these days is because the World DOES look more like the L.A of Blade Runner. Indeed, many Far-Eastern Cities look unerring like this. The design of the Film is stunning and inspired countless generations of Designers, not to mention Film Directors - Blade Runner has influenced Film like no other Science Fiction Film has.
The Cinematography is astounding - it just couldn't be anything else if you mix Ridley Scott with Jordan Cronenweth - the sheer look of the City, the streets and the interiors, all lit in a dark foreboding shadow-scape, are as 'Noir' as you can get. The Cast are superb, Harrison Ford has never been better and the support he gets from the likes of Rutger Hauer, Daryl Hannah, Joe Turkel etc is spot on. The score by Vangelis fits the atmosphere PERFECTLY - the scenes in Deckard's apartment to his 'memories of green' - are just pure Art.
In conclusion, this is a Science Fiction Film that takes it's subject seriously and consequently builds it's world to a standard that is rarely matched in Cinema. Many point to Kubrick's '2001' as the finest Film in this genre - I disagree - Ridley Scott's dark dystopian beauty has quietly stolen that crown.
reviews.heading: Beautiful Dystopia - the greatest most influential Sci-Fi Film ever made

reviews.content: Stunning visuals, and interesting worldbuilding. only critique is that the 3rd act lost a lot of momentum, and the ending therefore was a little less impactfull. but apart from that this is still one of the best films I've seen in a long time8/10: ooga booga
reviews.heading: ah yes

reviews.content: The best movie in a genre the Cyberpunk. It is still removed nothing at such level. Fine history which is given simply and interestingly. The post-apocalyptic future which is realistic though the movie was shot nearly 40 years ago. The ending open looks much better, than initial happy. After all she drops out of the concept of a plot. Cult movie!
reviews.heading: The best movie in a genre the Cyberpunk

reviews.content: Top list for one of the most overrated movies of all time, WAYY too slow with 0 substance, visually brilliant, kinda reminds me of "gangster saqud" in that regard. Looks good but might just be a waste of time.I gather most of the hype is due to the time it came out, i gather it must have been a revolutionary movie for the time, but most definitely doesnt stand the test of time.
reviews.heading: Slightly disappointed

reviews.content:
It's sad that so many people associated with this movie, (Ford- Hauer- Scott etc.) are so damn good and likable. Which is why I'm sad at just how overrated and terrible this movie is. And as most people with a functioning brain realize, grossly inferior to it's next of kin.
Don't even get me started at how bad Sean Young and Daryl Hannah are at their craft. Just pathetic. Ford is at his normal/average as is Hauer, but since the plot is so snail like slow and boring, you don't realize how average their performance really is.
If you want to see a really good sci fi flick, that won't put you to sleep, watch it's big brother. Everything about it is superior. Look, feel, emotion, (yes, it actually has some, unlike this snooze fest). Cgi is so much better. Yes I know they're years apart. But that's only because, they're years apart. No one will confuse the two. Except maybe the few brain dead 'cult' followers.
Do yourself a favor. Watch this with no expectations, and maybe you'll give it a generous 4 stars like me. Expect brilliance because of the fan boys and girls, and you will be forever let down.
reviews.heading: Just a really bad movie

reviews.content: I wanted to watch it because I wanted to know what happened before its sequel. I should not have done that. Yes, the movie looks great and it's cool visuals for an 80s film. BUT the story is really bad. The main plot, the world, etc is a nice idea but the story about the protagonist is just slow and boring.
reviews.heading: Cool looking waste of time

reviews.content:
Ok,
While Blade Runner was very pretty, the story was so convoluted that I had trouble understanding it. This is a movie you have to watch twice.
reviews.heading: Did I miss something?

reviews.content: How can you not give credit to a science fiction movie made in 1982 but still can be watched 2021 ? Ridley Scott's cult cyberpunk set the bar so high and so early. You can see traces of Blade Runner in many modern sci-fi production.
reviews.heading: Pioneer Sci-fi, still watchable today

reviews.content:
There aren't many films that are truly breathtaking. This is one such film. It's Avant Garde , adventurous , original , shocking , brutal , poetic , stunning , immersive, raw and unforgettable.
As a piece of sci-fi it is a love letter to the very heart of the genre. As a film it's a masterpiece on every level. It is, in every real sense , a life-changing experience.
reviews.heading: Astonishing

reviews.content: I was born in 1991 and I grew up watching this movie. Still holds up to this day. Beautiful film. If you're going to watch it make sure it's the final cut version!
reviews.heading: Never gets old

reviews.content: This film ais as basic as it gets. A Blade Runner is a guy who hunts replicants, so in this film he has to hunt down a few, that's the whole plot. There's also the boring theory about the identity of the protagonist, but it's just lame. On the other hand the visuals and music are stunning, they are very well done.
reviews.heading: Mediocre film with beautiful visuals.

reviews.content: This movie is extremely slow, with nothing to go off of in the story. When a movie is slow, you are kept on edge because something is about to go down, but I didn't feel that anticipation at all in blade runner. However, the movie is incredibly thought provoking, and you will be wanting answers. But watch the directors cut. That's the one you want, because that one raises the most questions. Overall, this movie carries through due to its brilliant message and social commentary, and it's stellar performances. It's a good movie, but not yet, in my opinion, one of the greats.
reviews.heading: Philosophical but slow

reviews.content: Blade Runner is a futuristic cyberpunk film by Ridley Scott, loosely based on the book "Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?" by legendary author Philip K. Dick. The visuals in this film are nothing short of awesome. You need to see this film to know what I am talking about. Also make sure to watch the Final Cut, that is Ridley Scott's most realized vision without the silly "happy ending" that showed in theaters. I can't say anything else about this film without you watching for yourself. This film is one-of-a-kind and very unique, go enjoy it for yourself.
reviews.heading: Amazing Effects and Awesome Style

reviews.content: Being a classic cult hit I thought I'd give this a try and that even if the genre wasn't my ideal that the story and pace would keep me engaged but it did not. I wanted to stop viewing after 20 minutes or so but powered through it just to see if it got better. The only positives of the movie for an early 80s film is that it is produced and shot very well. The scenery and backdrop are stunning for an older film. But I feel like you could have had the characters do anything else and it would have been better.I guess this movie is just not for everyone.
reviews.heading: Vastly disappointed and difficult to sit through

reviews.content: I didn't grow up with this movie but thought I'd better give it a go seeing how well it's rated.It was a decent movie overall, but nothing special. The pacing is a bit slower than more recent movies but was still interesting the whole way through.The dystopian feel of the movie was a bit corny and unconvincing at times but still worked.The ending scenes of the movie got a bit silly in my opinion, and changed the movie from having a mystery feel to feeling more like a thriller or horror, which I thought spoiled the experience and the story.Nevertheless, I would still watch it again, especially before watching Blade Runner 2049. Just don't set your expectations too high.
reviews.heading: Worth a watch

reviews.content: Blade Runner is one of best Sci fi of all time and even if i like some films more like Alien, Aliens and Terminator films at least first two this is still one great film full of memorable scenes ,interesting dialogue and conversations and cool fight scenes that hide some deeper staff inside them.Characters are also very interesting to follow and i even found myself feeling sorry for our villain in the end.Ford here give one of his best perfoamances ,while look of film and score are also brilliantly done.Blade Runner is one iconic Sci Fi
reviews.heading: Blade Runner

reviews.content: I watched this about 10-15 years back and I thought it was so long and boring, this movie is well within my wheelhouse of genre, cinematic "landscape", actors and soundtrack,now it being so long since my last watch I decided to give it another go to see if the last time I watched it I was somehow not of sound mind or just didn't grasp the full gravity of the movie.Well I guess something is lost on me for this movie, it has everything I should like but it is just a slog and a grind to get through, so much that I feel myself getting restless and hoping for something good to actually happen, I cannot see what others are seeing, maybe I saw it to late or maybe it's a cult classic to a certain people but what it is I don't think I'll ever understand.
reviews.heading: Second go at watching this "masterpiece"

reviews.content:
I first saw Blade Runner when it came out in the early 1980's and it didn't overly excite me, it was an ok sc-fi movie but nothing extraordinary. I decided to re-watch it again in 2020, and basically I have the same opinion. I had read lots of positive and glowing reviews of Blade Runner, so I thought I must have missed something all those years ago?
From my most recent viewing. The film has some amazing scenery and sets, even more so when you consider when it was made. The story isn't overcomplicated and easy enough to follow. Rick Deckard (Harrison Ford) a bounty hunter must hunt down 4 replicants (very life like robots) before they can cause chaos. One big downfall is the style that Harrison Ford plays his character, to me he came off mostly as a 1940's deadpan detective type, which didn't seem to work in the futurist world the movie is set in. The funny thing is how wrong the 1980's movie makers got what the world would be like in 2019! Sean Young and Rutger Hauer both do very well in portraying the troubled replicants, Rutger Hauer steals the show with his life like performance!
reviews.heading: Good but not great, like a replicant it's not what it really seems.

reviews.content: My imagining, is that there is/was a Ghost Room somewhere in the universe, perhaps overseen by Samantha Wormile. She isn't the original or the doppelganger Woman In Blue (The Woman In Blue - Sandy Hook - being from the same plane of reality as Terry Howletrax, although unlike Terry, the former woman has nothing to do with observation); indeed, in Blade Runner, the plane of existence aforementioned elicits some fantasy/reality fantasy along the lines of this doppelganger story . .The Woman In Blue is a self-made reality person - perhaps the very first self-made reality person - but, she is/was betrayed by a latter entity, who is conceptually but not biologically identical.Now, with that aspect-divulgence, I may as well use it - or elicit its theory of use - for the grander point about Blade Runner. Do people see - as in not see - shapes in front of them, 24/7? The Ashley Judd edge top, to the right (invoked by my Hill House review) shape-atmosphere would have to be one - which again, invokes the three act structure silliness - as would other types of shapes, known of or perceived by others.Access is the bridge - liar again; the bridge, provided by The Woman In Blue theory/sensibility, is for all intents and purposes the clinicalness of this, as opposed to an emotional and/or philosophical dimension.Thank you, to Harrison Ford, Ridley Scott, Sean Young and to Rutger Hauer
reviews.heading: Time for The Woman In Blue (Sandy Hook)

reviews.content: This movies is hands down the best science fiction movie ever made. The world they created is phenomenal. This movie is layered and saturated with originality. I can watch this one over and over again. I appreciate it more every time. The story is fantastic and leaves you with some unanswered questions that are up to the viewer to determine. I love this movie.
reviews.heading: Tears in the rain....

reviews.content: Atrocious acting and weak dialogue take away from an otherwise interesting story, cool retrofuturistic set designs, and dark, pretty visuals.
reviews.heading: Had more potential.

reviews.content: Blade Runner was hard for me to get into on my initial viewings, but is a brilliant well made film that once you give it a chance I was able to get into it. The film is visually astounding with excellent sets, f/x and cinematography. I t is a futuristic noirish thriller that is very bleak and gritty and very slow paced. The performances are top knotch from the cast and I found Harrison Ford to be brilliant as the lead, Rutger Hauer steals the show in his American debut as one of the best and coolest villains of all time. The score is perfect and is very subtle, but dark and ominous and helps create the mood and is perfect for this slow burn dystopian sci fi thriller. Although, I have to be in the right mood to watch Blade Runner, it was really well made and a great film for up and coming director Ridley Scott.
reviews.heading: Ridley Scott's bleak futuristic epic

reviews.content:
The film takes place in November 2019 in a decadent and futuristic city of Los Angeles decayed with pollution, exacerbated consumerism and the consequent search for new forms of colonization on other planets, to which people are invited to venture into the face of the collapse of human civilization, both materially and morally. It is noteworthy how visionary director Ridley Scott was, as globalization so widespread in recent decades, finds in this film, a catastrophic, melancholy and depressing ending - extinct animals are cloned and replicated following the main portion in the film - human replicants; the existence of a profusion of cultures, ethnicities, creeds and customs. Indeed, Mexicans, Chinese, Arabs and a whole range of cultures live together in this dark and discouraging environment.In addition to winning the famous cult movie title, Blade Runner is still considered one of the most influential films of the 1980s, both visually and by the suggestive script itself. In the film, the futuristic Earth of 2019 is the stage for a discussion on the right to life. More precisely, with regard to the very notion of life. When creating replicants, androids "more human than humans", do we have the right to use them as tools? Is a creature capable of developing feelings inferior to us because it was created out of our knowledge? If we can create a life form that can subdue our species, should we do that? These are questions posed by science fiction since then. From Artificial Intelligence to Westworld, through Jurassic Park and The Terminator, we always see human intelligence building its own extinction.If creating life out of nothing is read by various religions as proof of divine existence, the creation of the replicants elevates man to the level of God. And, in parallel with the Christian God of the Old Testament, our response to "rebellious children" is controlling, Manichaean and angry. In the textual preamble of Blade Runner, we are told that the ban on androids on our planet is a retaliation for their revolt at the condition of slaves. Just as God banished Adam and Eve from Paradise for eating the Forbidden Fruit, the "apple" that removed the innocence of the replicants was the conscience of their own bondage and the desire for freedom. What makes "Eden" paradoxical is its state: The Earth has been reduced to a great suburb, relegated to peripheral ethnicities (there are many Asian types in Blade Runner) and, mostly, to the poor. The rich can find true "paradise" in colonies off the planet. This idea of interplanetary segregation, it is worth noting, was taken up at Elysium. The replicants are banned from Earth precisely because the humans they are to serve are no longer here, but scattered throughout the Galaxy.On this dirty and marginal planet (a setting clearly inspired by film noir), the "detective" is the android runner hunter, "Blade Runner", Rick Deckard, forcibly removed from his retirement to "retire" the four fugitive replicants who entered the Earth. His investigation follows the same modus operandi as classic police films: informants from the streets, "little fish" thugs who are forced to give information to get rid of their own skin and an unexpected love affair. But, unlike the classic genre, Deckard is not the thread of the plot. The audience knows where the story is going to put its nemesis, the leader of the replicants Roy Batty (Rutger Hauer), a character intentionally built to show intelligence and humanity equivalent to those of his hunter. Roy, in further evidence that Ridley Scott built his film on biblical parables, is literally called by Eldon Tyrell (Joe Turkel), its creator, "prodigal son".
Roy is a character given to reinterpretations. In his presentation, he quotes America: A Prophecy, by William Blake, replacing a verb. "Flamed, the angels arose" becomes "flamed, the angels fell". This "mistake", which can be considered a sign of the fallibility of androids, would also explain the human characteristic present in them. A machine cannot analyze a literary work and adapt it to different contexts on a symbolic level. A human, yes. Roy and his companions found that their generation of androids is short-lived. In four years, they "die". That's why they return to Earth. Because they want to live longer. A basic desire of human nature in the face of the awareness of its finitude. He then seeks his creator, moved by the faith that he can help him. He discovers, however, that it is impossible, which reveals the weakness and impotence of the one who created it. Therefore, he denies and kills with his own hands the one who believed he was able to save him from death. Symbolically kills his only faith.The Voight-Kampff Test itself, a version of Philip K. Dick for the Turing Test, used to define who is human and who is replicant, raises a fundamental question: whether a machine is capable of developing feelings, something established by Tyrell in a conversation with Deckard, the Test may fail. Between Rachael (Sean Young), who believes he has lived memories that are not hers, but that provoke genuinely his feelings, and a psychopath, capable of committing heinous crimes without feeling empathy for the victims, where is the humanity of the second? At a philosophical level, it is fair to question whether the replicants do not have the human spark in them, as they were made in our image and likeness, just as, by Christian mythology, we have the Divine spark, because we were made in His image and likeness. This is the moment when the film confronts its protagonist with a possibility never before imagined by him. If a replicant can ignore his condition as a machine through the implantation of memories, what guarantees that he himself is not also one of them and his memories are all false?And this ambiguity about what defines humanity, whether the essence or existence (Pris, a replicant played by Daryl Hannah, quotes Descartes' "I think, therefore I am"), creates the best mystery in Blade Runner: Deckard is also a replicant? Ignoring comments from stakeholders and analyzing only filmic aspects, it is possible to say yes. On his piano, the score of Largo da Opera "Xerxes", by the German-British Händel. The play is an adaptation of a work by Giovanni Bononcini, which in turn adapted from Francesco Cavalli. Comparatively, a replicant is an adaptation of Man, which is an adaptation of God. Rachael previously questions Deckard if he has ever applied the Voight-Kampff Test to himself, and is answered silently. And, on the clearest clue of all, Gaff (Edward James Olmos), the same cop who recruited Deckard at the beginning of the film, leaves an origami unicorn at his door. Deckard had dreamed of a unicorn during the film, information he doesn't share with anyone. Just as he knew about Rachael's memories because they were not really hers, it is not absurd to imagine that Gaff knew about the unicorn because that memory was also implanted in Deckard.Harrison Ford's character takes on this ambiguity in an exceptional dimension, as it transcends his character and reaches his own condition, raising profound ethical questions related to his ambiguous nature: man or replicant? If he is really a replicant, the awareness of this puts him at the center of a tragedy: that of being an exterminator of his own kind. It is the curse of knowing, the curse of knowing yourself. Within ignorance, none of that mattered. However, once confronted with its existential condition, ethics imposes itself as a burden and its actions gain another perspective and density.Blade Runner is challenging and requires refined symbolic reasoning from its viewer to be understood, mainly by asking questions rather than offering answers. The visual construction of a decrepit Los Angeles, the direction of Scott that privileges the word over the action (although it does not neglect it in any way), and the iconic soundtrack created by the Greek musician Vangelis, made of purely melancholy chords, are elements that come into line to highlight the depth of the topics covered. Blade Runner is, without a doubt, one of the great science fiction films, less for its futuristic / visionary character, and more for the way it searches these existential questions, fitting them pertinently in the conflicts and contradictions of what is to come.
reviews.heading: Blade Runner is a great science fiction films, for its visual and existential questions, fitting them pertinently in the conflicts and contradictions of what is to come

reviews.content: On late eighties I used to reading a review at newspaper over the movies that'll be aired on week and thru this info l made my planning of my movie section on the night, was schedule to weekend Blade Runner which I never saw, according the famous reviewer Blade Runner was flopped on the box office, the audience didn't liked the Ridley Scott's offering, well watching this picture the proposal enthrall me deeply, how would be Los Angeles in 2019, an overcrowded dark city, with several ethnicities like Chinese, Indian and all sort of people working on narrow streets, including hidden replicants, created by Tyron Corporation, a kind of human being developed to work up at outer space on those hazardous mining activities in others planets, they had just four year of lifetime and they aren't allowed live on earth, although after a successful mutiny six of them escapes to Earth, Rick Deckard (Harrison Ford) as Blade Runner has an unwield assignment, finds out and destroy all them, L.A. has a bleak atmosphere seems nearly with Fritz Lang's Metropolis, including an iconic building at downtown, the painstaking director Ridley Scott had a total control of the movie's concept, managing with iron hand all departments at own relish, had a cohesive cast as Rutger Hauer, Sean Young, Daryl Hannah, Joanna Cassidy, Edward J. Olmos, M. Emmett Walsh and Brion Jones as main casting, shot just at night to deliver a gloomy atmosphere, also over a pouring rain and an overdone uses of steams, the plot is hard to digest at first glance, however is cryptically and endearing upon all aspects, I already watched three versions, a true masterpiece!!!Thanks for reading.Resume:First watch: 1989 / How many: 9 / Source: TV-DVD-Blu-Ray / Rating: 10
reviews.heading: My Masterpiece number 48!!!

reviews.content: I really, really tried.I have now watched every version of the film and even created THE definitive fan-edit, yet I still couldn't make the movie more than 'alright'.Unintentionally goofy at times, horrible editing in terms of pacing (the hardest part for me to correct), shallow script and even more shallow relationship between our leads.It's far from horrible, but I can't help but feel resentful at the 'legendary' status the film has received.If you want an 8/10 Sci-Fi experience in my book, go watch Planet of the Apes '68.
reviews.heading: I Tried...

reviews.content: This movie was very different from the usual sci fi movies that I have seen. It was very unique and different.The music and the visuals were absolutely stunning for its day and age since it is a very old movie. The acting and dialogue were well thought of and planned. THe plot was very simple and concise, and was well done. The tone or the vibe the movie gave off was sad and depressing, but I liked it though.I just had problems with the pacing. The beginning and the end were good but the middle was just so slow in my opinion. I know the director wanted the audience to be immersed and engaged in the slow scenes when the characters would talk too each other and the long stops between conversations. I tried to be engaged but I couldn't. And also I felt like they left a few questions unanswered and got me confused and irritated.From a netural stand point it was a good movie, it had its moments here and there, the ending was very emotionally moving, and the themes discussed in this movie was quiet unique from other sci fi movies during its time. For me personally I wouldn't watch it again though.Memorable: No Rewatchable: NO.
reviews.heading: Very deep movie..

reviews.content:
This is one of the rare cases where I prefer the movie over the book.
Stellar performance from Rutger Hauer, may he rest in peace.
reviews.heading: One of the best movies ever made. Period.

reviews.content: As great a movie as Blade Runner is, reviewing it is a little challenging simply because you have to decide which version you like and want to root for.BR has multiple endings and ways of being interpreted depending on which version you are watching and while I like that idea I would also like it if they just picked one.I went with the Final Cut (seems definitive enough).What makes Blade Runner so great (for me) is not the story or the questions regarding what is human etc its the incredible dystopian atmosphere that immerses you in to the world of Rick Deckard.If you get a chance to watch this at the cinema...take it :)
reviews.heading: Worthy of the adoration in receives

reviews.content: Rick Deckard (Harrison Ford), a cop who specialises in hunting down rogue androids (a 'Blade Runner'), has to deal with four deadly state-of-the-art synthetic renegades in a future (now an alternate) Los Angles, a seething warren of cramped alleys sprawling the shadows of brutalist megastructures. Drenched (literally and figuratively) in symbolism, style and mood, this cryptic film is more remembered for the striking visuals than the relatively simplistic story. Much has been written about director Ridley Scott's bleak dystopian vision and about the numerous versions (and the studio politics that created them). Having seen the film when it first came out in 1982, I remember the noir-ish voiceover that was absent on the version I recently watched on Netflix (presumably the longer, less expositional 'final cut'). The imagery in the film is marvelous (although there is little variation) and the crowded, culturally chaotic, media- and rain-saturated city established a novel 'future look' that was much imitated in later sci-fi films. The plot unfolds at a languid pace and viewers expecting an 'action film' may be disappointed, but as a piece of cinematic art (and history) the film has few rivals in the genre.
reviews.heading: Bleak, beautiful and stylish work of striking originality

reviews.content: What more can I say about 'Blade Runner' that hasn't already been said? A mix of dystopian sci-fi, film noir and philosophical meditation on life and humanity, its slow, melancholic style constitutes perhaps its most original contribution to the genre (aside from just about everything else). Vangelis' soundtrack gets a special mention from me.
reviews.heading: Offbeat, engrossing and dark

reviews.content: I must admit production is absolutely amazing and the movie is visual feast. Music is hunting but the plot is average. It's my personal opinion but it didn't quite catch my attention. Characters were there, and that's all I can say, none of them actually draw me in. I do recognise the mastery of that movie and its impact on futuristic cinema.
reviews.heading: Visually stunning but plot didn't capture me

reviews.content: I love movies, not just what is considered great but everything under the sun. I believe, how can your opinion matter unless you watch everything. Good is good, bad is bad, genre is irrelevant . With all that being said, I finally watched Blade Runner. Without writing something so long no one cares to read and at the same time not sounding pretentious, it's a visually cool looking film but that's about it. The story is very slow and before any one says it's about existentialism and questions what life is, STOP. If you have to ask what it is about, it doesn't deliver it's message. Watch it if you want to cross it of the list but your not missing anything substantial except some real well done special effects that still after 38 years look fantastic.
reviews.heading: I consider myself a cinephile and I've avoided this movie. I finally watched this and if your the same, here is in my opinion a unbiased review.

reviews.content: Its effects hold up to this day. Its visuals with its use of neon lighting and beautiful shadows make it one of the most stunning sci-fi films to look at. The plot is simple, but engrossing. The romance could be better (and less assaulty), but the implications of the ending and the film's equally great sequel paint it in an interesting new, if still not official light.Roy Batty is an amazing villain. His final speech will never not make me feel existentially depressed. Its themes of death are terrifying, but fascinating.Oddly enough, the "zoom and enhance" scene is my favorite in the whole movie. Final Cut is the best cut.It's great movie in almost every way. Beautiful.
reviews.heading: Blade Runner is the definitive cyberpunk movie.

reviews.content:
Sci-Fi, Philosophy, noir film, best Harrison Ford performance ever? Amazing Rutger Hauer, and all the cast, my God, what a bunch of awesome players are all of them, Edward James Olmos, even Darryl Hannah, the cinematography, the costumes, ths FX, the Music ( I think is the best score ever written by Vangelis Papatanasious, and it perfect for this flick).
Bottom line, if you do not like this film, you know nothing about filmaking at all...
reviews.heading: What a glorious film is this!!!!!!!!!!!

reviews.content: I've now watched the 3 main cuts of this over the course of decades. I just don't think I'm ever going to be a fan of it. The visuals are amazing (mostly), but the characters and plot, what little of either there are, just don't grab me.
reviews.heading: 3 different cuts

reviews.content: After so many years I have lost count of how many times I have watched this movie. I have also seen all the versions (i.e. theatrical, director's cut, final cut) that have come out over the years. I have obviously waited many years, 40+ of my lifetime, before I could make the statement that this is THE best sci-fi movie ever made. Perhaps a better one will be made, but for now this is it.Ridley Scott and his crew did an outstanding job. Across the three different versions, you can find one where the direction suit you best, each is Scott at the top of his game. Cinematography is absolutely stunning to this day. The script is excellent, which is no surprise as it was inspired by one of the best sci-fi short stories, Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep by the legendary Philip K. Dick. But the script stands on its own, and the crown achievement is of course the monologue by the late Rutger Hauer who passed away in 2019. Hauer not only delivered this striking monologue but he actually contributed to its brilliance by revising parts of the original script and making it one of the most beautiful script lines in movie history. It was Hauer passing and his powerful moments in this film that made me look back at this one more time and write this review.
reviews.heading: THE best sci-fi movie of all time.

reviews.content: Blade Runner is rightly considered as one of the best science fiction films of all time. For me, it is the second best (behind only 2001: A Space Odyssey) and one of the best films ever made. It is a 10/10 grade work with praise, it is a movie that gets better every time I watch it again, and I've watched it several times. It is one of the most reusable films for me, and every time I watch it, I discover something that I didn't notice the other time I watched it. I consider this the best film by legendary director Ridley Scott (and I say this knowing the merits of the masterpieces that are Gladiator and Alien).The final cut of this film is a masterpiece. It is much better musically, cinematographed and directed than the "normal" version. The additional scenes really make a stark difference here. Blade Runner is a film that was way ahead of its time. There are layers, philosophy, messages and meanings that are something that does not make this film a film that is just about a policeman going back to his work and doing what he already did. And even if it were just that, the film would be great already. To this day, there are many discussions about how complex Deckard is. Harrison Ford plays a great role as a character who has passions, dualities, humanity, but at the same time I thought he was a replicant. The famous "Unicorn Scene" gives several huge perspectives on what he really is, (or if he doesn't know what he is, as he himself indirectly speaks in a part of the film about Rachel).The film is visually magnificent. Its cyberpunk atmosphere of futuristic Los Angeles combined with excellent and revolutionary cinematography, coming from a director as visual as Scott, is one of the most beautiful films ever made. This super cool look becomes one of the most immersive films ever made. We entered, we plunged into that dystopia in a way that it is almost possible to smell that place. The bars, the streets, the interiors, everything is very immersive.Blade Runner's original soundtrack (especially from Final Cut) is mind-boggling. It can skillfully capture suspense, romance, existentialism, fear, fury, redemption, giving up ... It is also just one of the many reasons why this film is all of that.The secondary characters in Blade Runner are mostly fantastic. It is impossible to explain the greatness of each one of them, who fit this great script well.In the end, Blade Runner's Final Cut (1982) solidly materializes as one of the greatest films ever made. Many people say that this movie is "boring", but not a movie about wild explosions and wild action like any Marvel movie. But it is a film that does not have a fast pace. To develop his universe, characters are a story with complexities and depths like that of Blade Runner, a slower film was needed. This is not a weakness, as anyone who doesn't watch movies just for brainless entertainment knows how good a slower movie can be.
reviews.heading: Ridley Scott's Mix of Noir and Sci-Fi

reviews.content: A masterpiece of acting, writting and directing. This artwork places you in a rotten world, and exposes you all its sides so you can have a 360-degree view on a theme unknown to us. The writting miracle is supported by awesome shots and stunning performances. I would call it the absolute best sci-fi movie of all time.
reviews.heading: You'll be so immersed that you'll feel like you'll chocke

reviews.content: It's not often you get to say that a movie is better than the book it's based on but in this case it is.It's visually stunning and stylistic, sure, but it's also a philosophical deep dive, pondering life, death and what it means to be a human.Rutger Hauer does the performance of his life in Blade Runner and the depth of his character, Roy Batty, makes him much more than just another bad guy. This is especially witnessed in two very powerful scenes: The one when Roy kills his creator and the classic scene after he just saved Deckard's life.It's unfortunate that the sequel only managed to copy the stunning visuals and stylistic nature when the really good part lay in the philosophical pondering.
reviews.heading: Better than the book

reviews.content: This movie is beyond boring. 40 minutes into it and it is techinically beginning.The main reason for the slow progress are the excruciatingly slow scenes where the director wanted to show his futuristic scenarios, where it takes 5, 6 , 7 minutes just showing stuff around.Run away, this movie sucks.
reviews.heading: Excruciantly slow pace, lackluster plot.

reviews.content: Amazing visuals with a surprisingly complex and cerebral story.
reviews.heading: Amazing visuals

reviews.content: The greatest film of all time... It might be. I saw Blade Runner back when I was just a young boy (voice over and all) on VHS and it left me changed. This story, the environment and people within made perfect sense, amalgamated into a cohesive unit the likes my young eyes had never seen. Harrison Ford is a marval as deckard and Ridley Scott makes dark dystopical magi. If you've never seen it go see it now. If you have...the same. A Masterpiece pure and simple
reviews.heading: Tears+Rain=Perfect.

reviews.content: "Blade Runner" is a film of which at least everybody has heard the title on one occasion or the other and many, many people have seen it too if we take a look at the amount of ratings here on imdb. It is from the year 1982, so it will soon have its 40th aniversary and maybe this happened already depending on when you read my review. It runs for minimally under two hours and is based on a novel by Philip K. Dick, who sadly died of heart failure only months before this film got released. The two writers in charge of the screenplay here were Fancher and Oscar nominee Webb Peoples and both are still alive in their 80s now. But the big name here is of course director Ridley Scott, who has worked on many big movies over the course of his really long career, but the fact that this one here is a massive contender for being his biggest career success still says it all about the film's popularity. The one person where this is probably not a contender for most popular film is lead actor Harrison Ford, but this is only because he was also a crucial player in the Star Wars franchise. And let's not forget about Indiana Jones of course. I have never been a big fan of either and consequently also not a big fan of Ford, but he was alright here. The fact that he does not necessarily play a very likable man as I would say is kinda explained at the end. But I will get to that later.First, a few more words on the cast: There are many cast members in smaller roles that I am not familiar with, even if they are/were also prolific actors. But one mention goes out to Sean Young, who plays the maybe most interesting character from this film. Easily the most stunning though I would say. Daryl Hannah's character is called "perfect" on one occasion by another character, but I could not disagree more. Young is perfect here in my opinion. Then again, I have always had a soft spot for dark-haired girls, so certainly biased here. So I mentioned Hannah now, she was very young here of course and most people are also familiar with her from the Kill Bill films and I must admit I did not even remember she was in this film here although, especially with the makeup, her character here is pretty memorable and interesting too. The scene right before the fight when she is in disguise in a similar manner like Bond going against Scaramanga was nice too, but Ford/Deckard is too much of a professional to not spot her quickly, even if he is still taken by surprise by her. Edward James Olmos, another very established actor in here, also plays an interesting character who kind of could have deserved his own film too. And last but not least, Rutger Hauer. Sadly he passed away not too long ago, but this film is maybe his most iconic performance and with the twist towards the end, I can totally see why. He is strong, he is ruthless, but he is much more than that. I will elaborate a bit on that later on.Just one more thing here about the main character and his love interest: We see the two leave eventually and it's not safe to say if others will be on their tails, on her tail especially, but the scene with the little thingey on the ground in the end implies that they may have gotten help from the Asian guy, who made it look as if she was dead, so nobody will know she is still alive and on the run. Actually, a strong premise for a sequel too and that sequel came, but no less than 35 years later and I must say I did not like the sequel at all, maybe because I hadn't seen or wasn't too familiar with the original, but then again it should never be essential to have seen a film in order to appreciate another. Still, it got Roger Deakins an Oscar finally, so it's good it exists. Also, another interesting thing about the original here is that it is set in 2019 as we find out at the very start, so in the past now as we are in 2020. Always an interesting aspect how people saw the future back then.Okay, now I want to elaborate a bit on the story and scenes and inclusions that I liked the most. Must initially give a brief summary of the premise. Mankind created replicants, man-like creatures that are as smart as the smartest men and stronger than the strongest. And they are very pain-resistent too. On one occasion, they said that the only way to hurt them, is to kill them. However, conflicts arose and war was declared against said replicants who were at distant planets and had to work as slaves. In this movie, six replicants manage to flee and come to planet Earth. Two of them were killed immediately and a bit of a pity that we find out nothing else about those. The other four get decent inclusions though, at least two of them also considerable screen time. The snake woman does not. She is the first who gets found by Deckard and he manages to take her down after a fight. Immediately afterwards, the protagonist runs into the second replicant and is basically caught with his pants down by him (just metaphorically), but luckily an unexpected ally is there to save his life. Two remain.Hannah's character is the third. It is kinda interesting how Deckard takes down one by one just like the Bride does in "Kill Bill". Anyway, as for this one here, Hannah is eventually still at her buddy Sebastian's home and that place is indeed very creepy somehow and extremely bizarre with all the lights and of course the mechanical creatures that Sebastian considers his friends. He is a weirdo, but not an evil man. He has no real choice other than helping the replicants. Hauer's character is mostly interested in an idea how he can keep himself alive for more than four years. Or actually cares more about keeping Hannah's character alive. This is how long the replicants have. Not a lot. There is a good quote about a parallel they have compared to light bulbs. And that is why he wants to see Joe Turkel's character and well, of course it is pretty shocking and violent and brutal how the latter gets murdered eventually, but you can make a bit of a point for this being not motivated by hate or anything, but just by hopelessness and desparation against the man who caused this by creating the replicants with a life span of four years and there is no option to have them live longer as we find out while they discuss all kinds of scientific processes.Now, the one thing I want to elaborate on most of all here is the definition of who is the offender and who is the victim. We follow Ford's character and he represents one side here and of course we side with him sooner or later, but at the same time we forget how he was recruited here early on. He had no choice, but was literally forced by his boss to follow his orders. Apparently, he worked for him or for the agency in the past already and he clearly was not happy at all with it back then and just hoped he could get away, but he has no choice. Maybe the one thing missing here a bit is an explanation of why they are called blade runners, but that is just a minimal criticism. Anyway, take a look at how Ford's character shoots the first replicant. She is running from him, trying to be safe, to get away, but gets murdered in cold blood. You can call it that. There is not too much to say about the second victim. Of course, it is another fight about life and death for him. But seeing Hannah's character die is also very telling being in disguise before that and eventually on the ground like a severely wounded animals. That is what the replicants are: Animals. Slaves. But all their violence results from what was done to them and not from being evil or anything. Not at all.Then with Hauer's character, there is the big revelation. Yes he breaks Deckard's fingers, but he does so because his loved ones were taken from him and apparently he also knew that it was not Deckard who killed the other male replicant, so only two fingers. Also pay attention to the hands. Roy (Hauer) easily could have broken Deckard's hand in that situation, maybe torn it off even, but he lets go. And his own hand is very injured. It may be the wildness, the muscles we see as Hauer's character runs around topless that has him appear like a beast to us, but that is what he is, again an injured monster and one who is stronger than the others. He is called the prodigal son for good reason earlier. And when we have that shot outside in the pouring rain with Deckard being in danger of falling to his death, but Roy lends him a hand and pulls him up before dying himself making his last deed an act of mercy shows us that he is not evil and neither are the other replicants. That camera shot from down there pointing up to Roy with the dove in his hand is pretty massive and very memorable, also how he lets the dove go in the moment of his death. Okay, maybe a bit unrealistic that this exact moment the Asian guy is there, but okay. Everything before that was so brilliant that I can accept it.In-between, I had several moments where I thought I could actually give this four stars out of five and not just three and thus declare it as one of 1982's finest, but the final sequence with Hauer's character on the chase was initially a bit underwhelming I felt, so I was hesitant, but the final twist and explanation about goodness, mercy and perspective (like I said in the title of my review) were just too good to be ignored. The film also could have ended the moment Hauer's character died, but the epilogue is also tolerable I suppose, even if it was not necessarily required. Without it, we would have thought that Rachael left and will not be followed and hunted down by Deckard as he owes her. That's what he said himself. But yeah, it's the message about (not just) slavery and about people only wanting the best for them without being evil. Only being heartbroken and disappointed may bring out the worst in them. Or how it matters so much from which perspective you watch a movie in how you perceive the characters. But they are 100% authentic, also showing their "love" in front of Sebastian. Watch it!
reviews.heading: A wonderful movie on perspective and also extremely entertaining

reviews.content: This is what u can't expect from science fiction films specially from 80s.

reviews.content: This has stood the test of time. A beautiful film which ultimately looks at what it is to be human.
reviews.heading: Masterpiece of Science fiction

reviews.content: I get the feeling that a lot of people watch Blade Runner expecting it to be a sci-fi action thriller in the vein of Star Wars, or at least be more action-oriented than it is. But, even though it's visceral and different, Blade Runner is a classic once you get past the disappointment at the lack of laser fights.Taking after Philip K. Dick's novel, Blade Runner is more of a commentary on the role of technology in society. And the depths and lengths to which it goes to explore the issue are incredible. It's a film with layered characters, dialogue laden with undertone and a whole lot of metaphor and motif.Harrison Ford has found his own in another role seemingly written for him. He plays the disenchanted protagonist excellently (a la Star Wars and Indiana Jones), and this time is met with a wonderful opposite in Rutger Hauer's Roy, an antagonist whose morality and motives are put into question right until the end of the film. It's one of those stories that offers more questions than it does answers, leaving you pondering what it all meant and what happens next.I always enjoy a film that leaves its thematic question open to interpretation. Blade Runner never settles on who the "good guy" or the "bad guy" is, but instead poses you a question and leaves you to consider it for yourself.7 out of 10, definitely don't expect a space opera, and expect it to make you think.
reviews.heading: It's not what you expect, but it's still brilliant

reviews.content: The visuals and score are dystopian. That is good. The plot, the characters, the action scenes are uninteresting. That is bad. By the end of the flick I literally did not care if either the humans or the replicants lived or died by the end.
reviews.heading: A rather dull edge to the blade

reviews.content: I watched this movie for the first time not too long ago and at first I didn't know what to think of it. It seems like a straight forward crime noir story, but it takes that concept and turns it into so much more. The film constantly (although subtly) calling into question Deckard's true identity. It seems very apparent as the film goes on what the true answer is, but it is never fully addressed. That is the genius of this film. It has so much hidden subtext in it. I love this film and like Ridley Scott's other work Alien, it is a Masterpiece and a movie that will go down in history as one of the greatest stories ever told through film.
reviews.heading: I can see why everyone loves this movie

reviews.content: I didn't like this film as much as others do. As much as it was influential on the science fiction genre and a streamlined adaptation of the original Phillip K. Dick classic, I didn't think it was as deep as its reputation suggests. The pacing itself is quite slow but without much benefit. To be honest, I think its sequel is much better.
reviews.heading: Brooding

reviews.content: The Godfather 2 of Sci-Fi. Watching this is an almost transcendental experience that transports you into the best world-building ever put on the big screen.I've never seen cyberpunk so well realized, and to think this was all made in 1980 with real sets, real lighting, and real weather effects makes it all the more mind-blowing.Based off an alternative timeline that began in sprawl/freeway inception of the 1950s, Blade Runner combines 20th century concepts like hyper scale globalization, environmental collapse, and techno-obsessive city planning to project a sort of nightmarish collage of all our old and present fears about the rot of modernity by showing us a vision of 2019 Los Angeles as a city of 100 million global refugees (likely because of a small scale nuclear war which made most cities uninhabitable and caused many to migrate here).The way this movie portrays depth and claustrophobia is masterful. I really feel like I'm an inhabitant of this insane nightmare city whenever we see its dozens of outdoor sequences.Storywise it's one of the greats of science fiction history as well. It's a slow-burning atmospheric thriller that stuns you with how well it's intellectual ideas blend with the overall film and aren't in your face or too hard to notice. It's a film about what makes life worth living, what defines consciousness, and the many gray areas of ethics that exist in its universe.10/10- A Masterpiece
reviews.heading: Have A Better One!

reviews.content: I don't know if i'm hideous or not , but i totally didn't get the movie's main idea , everybody is just complimenting the movie and the director which i don't really understand why , i found it really standared it was perhaps a bit queer but it was normal at the same time i just enjoyed the acting and the stunning visuals while not understanding what in the world is going on ....

reviews.content: First of all "R.I.P. RUTGER HAUER" this movie transcends time & will always be a blue print for how sci-fi should be done, Blade Runner gives you characters and a storyline that keeps you hook, if you don't own this get it!!!!!

reviews.heading: A cult classic

reviews.content: Can't think of a better example of something that manages to entertain so many people, but is actually pure art! Maybe Christopher Nolan movies come close?
reviews.heading: Art meets Entertainment

reviews.content: Science fiction is a genre that I love exploring and Blade Runner is regarded as one of the best sci-fi films ever made which is something I couldn't agree more.Blade Runner follows Deckard, a blade runner, whose job is to find and kill four replicants that have arrived on Earth to find their maker.Blade Runner isn't like any other sci-fi film I've seen. This is a film that doesn't contain an abundance of action but rather focuses more on the world we're presented with and for me that's the biggest selling point. For a film that came out in 1982, it's impressive how amazing the production design is. Ridley Scott fully immerses you into this dystopian, futuristic universe and the beautiful music composed for this film adds a layer of atmosphere to it. Alongside that Scott gives us a story that deals with a lot of themes. Whether it's relating to memories or what it means to be human, Blade Runner provides us with something really unique and complex. It surprised me how deep this film actually goes once you actually analyse it.People may be upset by the slow pacing and lack of action but I loved the way Scott told this story. This is what separates Blade Runner from other sci-fi films and it's the slower pacing that lets the viewer soak in the film's dystopian atmosphere and philosophical messages. The performances are great especially Harrison Ford and Rutger Hauer who are a treat to watch.Blade Runner is certainly not a film for everyone. It's not mainstream but the way Ridley Scott directs this film and the astounding production design make Blade Runner special. The fact that so many films later on took ideas from Blade Runner shows how influential it is. I would definitely recommend it.
reviews.heading: One of the best sci-fi films made

reviews.content: I had to turn it off halfway through, I was bored out of my mind. I liked the visuals but that's about it. I don't get why everyone seems to love this movie.
reviews.heading: I honestly do not see what all the buzz is about.

reviews.content: It's rare to see cyberpunk done so well. I really enjoyed the world building and how tactile it looks. The smoke and rain really added to the neo noir effect. I also really liked the visuals of the film and thought it was scored well. I will say I got a little bored towards the middle, but overall I can see why it has cult classic status. Give it a watch if you are into older sci fi.

reviews.heading: Time Passes On

reviews.content:
I would even say that I disliked it more the second time around than the first time. First time I gave this movie an 8 but after the second viewing I give this movie a 6. This a mess of a movie with shallow characters, uninteresting plot, messy script and weird performances. The visuals, music and cinematography are the only things that are good in this movie. But to what good are these, when you can't transmit a message through the story, characters and dialogues? The visuals only enhance the experience but when you have no experience what is there then to enhance? You can skip the part where I break down the plot of the movie.Plot breakdown:
So the movie begins with a short text describing the state in which the world is at the time the movie happens. But there is no effort put in explaining how the world got there or some kind of context to what is happening in order to care about what happens. And people (myself included) hate the new Star Wars for having no context to their stories, but the same people love this movie for basically doing the same thing. Next we see an interview which ends with the person being interviewed shooting the interviewer, even though he appeared to be a prisoner with no weapon with him. The problems with this scene are 1. we have no idea who these people are and 2. we don't know why that is relevant to the plot. Next we meet Deckard who is a former Blade Runner who used to retire robots known as Replicants. He gets a mission of retiring 4 Replicants that have gone rogue
but again the problem with this scene is that the person giving him this task doesn't explain it properly so basically the viewer is still in the dark about what is going on in this movie and why should he be invested in it. The movie however does something good next and that these two go and see the 4 Replicants on a monitor screen. That sheds some light on who is who and why is that relevant to the plot. Next Deckard goes to the creator of the robots named Tyrell. There he meets a Replicant named Rachel and he starts questioning her to see if she is a human or a Replicant. The problem here is that I as a viewer have no idea about this questioning and how someone should respond as a human to it and how should a Replicant respond to that. So basically I was bored to tears and not captivated durign this scene. Not to mention not being able to see the so-called or claimed to be philosoficall questioins or themes this scenes rises. I'm sorry movie! Then Deckard finds a clue and then investigates and finds the first Replicant. But I have to be honest, I haven't seen more uninteresting and uncaptivating detecting skills than this couple of scenes in this movie, in any other movie ever! Nothing is known to me so that I may observ how Deckard finds another angle to it and finds out something I missed. It's just plain bad and boring! So he tracks the first Replicator also a female and shoots her. Then Leon the second Replicant finds him and is about to kill him but then Rachel shows up and shoots Leon. BTW Leon was the Replicant shown in the first scene of the movie. Wow that should be so mind blowing, except it's not because there was nothing interesting about 1. that interview or 2. this scene in particular. Forgot to mention Rachel came earlier to Deckard's appartment and then left. I also forgot to mention that before Leon found Deckard he was with Roy, the so called leader of this group of Replicants and tried to find out who could improve them and make them last. BTW their life span was only 4 years. Then Deckard takes Rachel home and forces her to love him and make out with him. And although this romance seemed forced I gotta say the two actors have chemistry together and therefore their relationship was the most interesting and captivating thing in this movie. Then Roy's girlfriend and the last Replicator finds JF Sebastian who was just a tool to get to Tyrell. Sebastian was basically a Tyrell
wanna-be and was just as interesting as the movie itself for me. So Roy gets to Tyrell and kills him for being disappointed that he could not prolong his life to more than 4 years. Oh, he also kills Sebastian. So now somehow Deckard knows where JF Sebastian lived and finds there Roy's girlfriend and kills her so Roy gets mad, starts acting weird like unclothing himself taunting Deckard, piercing his hand with a nail and then at the end when Deckard is danger of falling down and dying he saves him, monologues and then dies. Wait a minute! Weren't the Replicants' lifespan 4 years? At the beginning we are told it was November 2019 and Roy was made in 2016 so he should last 'till 2020 right? Wrong! After he monologues he tilts his head down and dies. Like why? What killed him? His monologue? Then Deckard picks up Rachel and escapes somewhere where he and she could never be found. And that's it that's the pot of Blade Runner.End of Plot breakdown.What a complete mess of a movie. These are tow hours (or better said 4 hours) of my life I'll never get back. There are so many problems with this movie. From the ugly and unfuturistic setting of the movie to the fact that every single moment of this movie happens either during the night or during a night with rain. Like why? Why is there no daylight? Is that because of the industry of the world and how that is poluting and thus the sun couldn't shine? I mean it's looks nice but after a while it gets really boring and repetitive. The future is so ugly and I don't have a problem with a future where everything seems rotten or old, but this seems just like an 80's world with flying cars and big buildings. There is nothing in the realm of technology that looks even remotely similar to what those things look like in 2019/2020. It's just very unbelievable and not actually authentic and interesting. But that's a prblem most of the pre 2000 sci-fi movies have and that they show a very unfuturistic world. Not to mention the amatuerish editing that jumps from the scene presenting the replicants to something else instead of showing us after that the replicants in order for us to get familiarized with them and know why when some of them die, that is important for the plot. No, the movie jumps to something completely different so then when it jumps back on the first watch at least, is very confusing to know who is who and get involved into it.All in all this movie is a mess and one of the most overrated movies of all time, having no philosofical themes or moral questions about what's like to be human, boring characters, uninteresting script and boring plot. That basically is the same problem Blade Runner 2049 has. Oh well...
reviews.heading: Even after the second viewing I still don't like this movie

reviews.content:
Blade Runner (1982) - The Final CutWhat I liked -
The Final cut that is on Netflix is a movie that is so far ahead of its time, it blows my mind. I cannot fathom the level of foresight the screenplay, cinematography and direction required to make this movie back in 1982. Throughout the movie, you're treated to awesome displays of graphics, costume and dystopian vibes. I'm positively sure that Blade Runner gave birth to the cyberpunk era and has been the foundation for so many dystopian movies that have emerged since then. Harrison Ford, as always did a commendable job.What I didn't like - Blade Runner is a movie where the quality of the plot is neglected because everything else is so good. In my opinion, the plot is shallow and not that exciting. The movie is slow and takes it time to build up and the payoff at the end is not what you would expect.In a nutshell, Blade Runner is a visual spectacle without much substance. What is most important out of this movie is that it led to the rise of so many other beautiful creations.

reviews.content: It is captivating to see how things today were imagined in the 1980s, mostly in visual terms. Depictions of the future, technological progress, science and corporations are also interesting. Looking back, this film is clearly seminal for the sci-fi tradition that came afterwards. However, the plot is poor and I do not understand why many people have said it is "philosophical". From my point of view, the movie reflects a huge concern/fear about the ultra development of technology and the threat it could represent for humanity, but it doesn't explore any tension around this. There is never any doubt about who are the bad guys and who are good guys.
